It is effected by the love of Heracles for IolÃ¨, which causes him to destroy Oechalia, and also causes Deianeira to send the robe; thus bringing the two episodes into a strict connection. Professor Campbell is, in my opinion, quite right when he says that â€˜in point of dramatic structure the Trachiniae will bear comparison with the greatest of Sophoclean tragedies.â€™ For, even if, as I hold, the inferiority in dramatic interest of Heracles to Deianeira is such as to constitute a serious defect, this is not a defect of structure. It does not concern the manner in which the plot has been put together. It concerns something antecedent to the plot; namely, the conception of Heracles adopted by the poet, as compared with his conception of Deianeira. Given those two conceptions, the most perfect dramatic structure could not save the interest in Heracles from being overpowered by the interest in Deianeira.

Unity of time neglected.There is, however, one point in which the texture of the plot is fairly open to criticism, though it is not a point of importance. The â€˜unity of timeâ€™ has been disregarded with exceptional boldness. Hyllus goes to Euboea, witnesses the sacrifice there, and returns to Trachis, in a space of time measured by less than 700 lines (vv. 93â€”734). Nay, Lichas, who leaves Trachis at verse 632, had reached Euboea before the sacrifice began. Many other examples show the habitual laxity of Greek dramatists, and the tolerance of Greek audiences, in this particular. But in the Trachiniae the license has a special excuse. Amid the excitement, the alternations of hope and fear, which pervade this play, the action hastens forward in a manner which leaves us no leisure to remark the feats of travelling performed by Hyllus and by Lichas. This is the case even with readers; much more would it be so with spectators. And here we may observe the subtlety of the poet, who has introduced two direct allusions to the passage of time. Lichas, about to start for Euboea, remarks that he has already stayed too long (v. 599); and the Chorus prays that the ship which is bringing Heracles â€˜may not tarryâ€™ (v. 655). This is like the art of a diplomatist who diverts suspicion by apparent frankness.

Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Î´â€™ á¼Î½ á½‘ÏƒÏ„á½³Ïá¿³ Î¼á½³Î½, á¼€ÏƒÎ¼á½³Î½á¿ƒ Î´á½³ Î¼Î¿Î¹, ğŸ—©
Line 18

After the two dramas of the Attic masters, Heracles Seneca's Hercules Oetaeus. appears only once in the extant literature of ancient Tragedy. Seneca founded his Hercules Furens on the play of Euripides, and his Hercules Oetaeus on the play of Sophocles. It would be profitless to institute a detailed comparison between the Trachiniae and a work which Seneca, in the fashion of his day, composed rather as a rhetorical exercise than as a piece for the stage. Those who read it, with the Greek model present to their minds, can only wonder how the Roman's brilliant gifts of expression, â€”which shine in epigram and, at moments, reach a true elevation of sentiment,â€”could co-exist with such abject tastelessness, such extravagance of bombast, such insensibility to proportion. Yet, in one respect, a comparison is very interesting. If the Phaedra of the Hippolytus has fared ill at Seneca's hands, far worse is the transformation which he has effected in the Deianeira of the Trachiniae. The following lines describe The Latin Deianeira Deianeira's behaviour when IolÃ¨ first arrives at Trachis:â€” Ut fulsit Iole, qualis innubis dies Purumve claris noctibus sidus micat, Stetit furenti similis ac torvum intuens Herculea coniuxHerc. Oet. 238 ff.,â€” like â€˜an Armenian tigress,â€™ the poet adds, or â€˜a Maenad shaking the thyrsus.â€™ Then Deianeira prays Juno to torment Heracles with all imaginable plaguesHerc. Oet. 255 ff.; and finally avows her own readiness to kill himIb. 436.. Certainly Seneca has protected our sympathy with the hero from competition; but the hero himself, bragging and whining by turns, fails to profit by that advantage. The Hercules Oetaeus became the model of Rotrou, in his tragedy entitled Hercule MourantPublished in 1632. Rotrou gave Heracles a successful rival in the affections of IolÃ¨, a certain Arcas. The dying hero forbade IolÃ¨ to marry Arcas; but, after his apotheosis, he showed his magnanimity by descending from Olympus on purpose to revoke the veto.; and also influenced, in a greater or less degree, several other French dramas on the same themeM. Patin, Etudes sur les trag. grecs, vol. II. p. 89.. It was inevitable that the Latin writer, rather than Sophocles, should be imitated by a French dramatist of the seventeenth century. Apart from this, however, the Deianeira of Seneca, considered as a general type, would be more truly congenial to the French stage. It was difficult for the Latin races to imagine a woman, supplanted in her husband's love, who did not wish to kill somebody,â€”her rival, or her husband, or both. Ovid's Deianeira is by no means so bad as Seneca's; but she, too, has the impulse to destroy IolÃ¨Ovid Met. 9. 151.. The Deianeira of the Trachiniae, with anguish in her soul,â€”intent on regaining her lord's heart, but not angry, not malevolent towards him or towards IolÃ¨,â€”this Deianeira is a creation of the Hellenic spirit, refined by the sweetness, the purity, the restrained strength of Athens at her best; if any one would see the spiritual kinswomen of this Deianeira, he must look for them on the grave-reliefs of the Cerameicus.

The fable

á½ ÎºÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼¦Î»Î¸Îµ Î–Î·Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼ˆÎ»ÎºÎ¼á½µÎ½Î·Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Ï€Î±á¿–Ï‚Â· ğŸ—©
Line 19

The wide range of subjects or motives which the Heracles legends gave to Greek art of every period includes, of course, several episodes mentioned in the Trachiniae;â€”the combat of Heracles with AcheloÃ¼s; the death of Nessus; Heracles with the Eurytidae; the death of Iphitus; the servitude to Om phalÃ¨See Roscher's Lexicon der gr. und rÃ¶m. Mythologie, where, under â€˜Herakles,â€™ the illustrations of the fable in art are fully treated by FurtwA. Ã¤ngler. He recognises Iphitus on a vase in the Louvre (no. 972), where Heracles is hurling a man from a ÎºÎ»á½·Î½Î·, apparently during a meal (p. 2233). Cp. Hom. Od.21. 28: Heracles, in slaying Iphitus, Î¿á½Î´á½² Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ á½„Ï€Î¹Î½ á¾Î´á½³ÏƒÎ±Ï„), Î¿á½Î´á½² Ï„Ïá½±Ï€ÎµÎ¶Î±Î½ | Ï„á½´Î½ Î´á½µ Î¿á¼± Ï€Î±Ïá½³Î¸Î·ÎºÎµÎ½. Sophocles follows the version according to which Iphitus was hurled from a high wall or tower ( Soph. Tr.273).â€”There is no certain example of OmphalÃ¨ in art before the Hellenistic period (ib. p. 2234: cp. p. 2247).. But, in relation to the legends of Heracles, Attic Tragedy, represented by the Mad Heracles and the Trachiniae, had no direct influence upon art, such as can be traced, for instance, in regard to Philoctetes. For the story of Heracles, artists drew upon other, generally older, sources of poetry or tradition. When, indeed, in Hellenistic and Roman times a degenerate Heracles became the type of a strong man easily enthralled by pleasure, a companion of the Bacchic thiasos or of the ErÃ´tesSee FurtwÃ¤ngler, ap. Roscher, p. 2248., then the art which desired to portray him often went for material to the theatre; but such material was furnished by the Heracles of Comedy or of satyr-drama. It is not surprising, then, that the illustrations of the Trachiniae which Greek art affords are only of a general kind. For example, each of the three successive forms assumed by the AcheloÃ¼s of the Trachiniae, when he was a suitor for Deianeira, can be separately identified in works of artSee commentary on v. 11.. But, though the fight of Heracles with AcheloÃ¼s was a subject often treated by artists, no extant representation of that combat corresponds precisely with the scene as described by SophoclesThe nearest approach to an illustration of the poet's text is given by an archaic gem, now in the British Museum, first published (roughly) in King's Ancient Gems, II. pl. 34, fig. 3. Mr Murray S. has kindly given me an impression of it. Yet even this diverges from Sophocles in three particulars. (1) On the gem, AcheloÃ¼s is the man-headed bull,â€”a frequent type, but not one of those specified by the poet. (2) Deianeira stands lamenting, close to the combatants; whereas the poet describes her as sitting by a hill at some distance from the fray. (3) There is no trace of AphroditÃ¨, whom Sophocles mentions as present with the combatants in the quality of umpire..

20 á½ƒÏ‚ Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼€Î³á¿¶Î½Î± Ï„á¿·Î´Îµ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï€ÎµÏƒá½¼Î½ Î¼á½±Ï‡Î·Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 20

We have now considered the nature of the legendary Diction. material used in the Trachiniae; the character of the treatment applied to it by the poet; and the principal features of the tragedy viewed as a work of dramatic art. An introduction to this play must also, however, take account of its style in a more limited sense,â€”the style of its poetical diction, the complexion of the language. For the details of this subject, reference must necessarily be made to the commentary on the text. But a few general observations may properly be offered here.

Successive phases in the style of Sophocles.It is a well-attested tradition, and one which can still be partially verified, that the style of Sophocles, like that of many other great poets, was developed through successive phases, belonging to successive periods of his life. He himself, according to Plutarch Mor.p. 79 B. (Î á¿¶Ï‚ á¼„Î½ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Î±á¼´ÏƒÎ¸Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿ á¼‘Î±Ï…Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€ÏÎ¿Îºá½¹Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á¼Ï€â€™ á¼€ÏÎµÏ„á¿‡, c. 7.) á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ Î³á½°Ï á½ Î£Î¿Ï†Î¿ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ á¼”Î»ÎµÎ³Îµ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î‘á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î»Î¿Ï… Î´Î¹Î±Ï€ÎµÏ€Î±Î¹Ï‡á½¼Ï‚ á½„Î³ÎºÎ¿Î½, Îµ<*>Ï„Î± Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Î¿Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á¿†Ï‚, Ï„Ïá½·Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼¤Î´Î· Ï„á½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î»á½³Î¾ÎµÏ‰Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±Î²á½±Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½ Îµ<*>Î´Î¿Ï‚ á½…Ï€ÎµÏ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ á¼ Î¸Î¹Îºá½½Ï„Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î²á½³Î»Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½, Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰Ï‚ Î¿á¼± Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿ÏƒÎ¿Ï†Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„ÎµÏ‚, á½…Ï„Î±Î½ á¼Îº Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ï€Î±Î½Î·Î³Ï…ÏÎ¹Îºá¿¶Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Ï‰Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Ï€Ï„á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ á¼¤Î¸Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½±Î¸Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±Î²á¿¶ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á¼„ÏÏ‡Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Î¹ Ï„á½´Î½ á¼€Î»Î·Î¸á¿† Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ¿Ï€á½´Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼„Ï„Ï…Ï†Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Îºá½¹Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½., distinguished three such phases. In the earliest, he had imitated the majesty, the pomp,â€”á½„Î³ÎºÎ¿Ï‚,â€”of Aeschylus. Next came the style which, in Plutarch's notice, is described by the words, Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Î¿Î½ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±Ï„Î±ÏƒÎºÎµÏ…á¿†Ï‚. This was a style marked by subtle elaboration, and, as a result of it, by Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá½¹Î½, â€˜pungency,â€™ â€˜incisivenessâ€™; a style in which terse and polished force of expression drove home the â€˜stingâ€™ of word or phrase;â€”as Eupolis,â€”to borrow an illustration from a different, yet cognate, province,â€”said that the incisive and highly wrought oratory of Pericles left its â€˜stingâ€™ in the minds of those who heard him: Ï„á½¸ Îºá½³Î½Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ á¼Î³ÎºÎ±Ï„á½³Î»Î¹Ï€Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ á¼€ÎºÏÎ¿Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚. Such a style, with its affinities to an elevated and refined rhetoric, can be a source of great brilliancy and power in poetry; but its essential quality is not that which constitutes the highest excellence of drama: its defect, for the purposes of drama, is that it is too suggestive of conscious effort in the artist; its tendency is to image his mind somewhat too strongly in the persons whom he wishes to make live upon the scene. Hence we readily comprehend the words in which Sophocles (according to Plutarch) defined the third, the final, phase of his style;â€”Ï„á½¸ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î»á½³Î¾ÎµÏ‰Ï‚ Îµá¼¶Î´Î¿Ï‚ á½…Ï€ÎµÏ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½¶Î½ á¼ Î¸Î¹Îºá½½Ï„Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î²á½³Î»Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½: â€˜the kind of diction which is most expressive of character, and bestâ€™; that is, fittest to make each person of the drama seem a real human being; and best, therefore, for the purposes of a dramatist.

The first of these three phases, the Aeschylean, is not traceable in the extant work of Sophocles. Nor can it be said that any one of the seven tragedies represents the second style in a form which sharply distinguishes it from the third; that is, in a form from which the characteristic quality of the third style is absent. But, if the Philoctetes, one of the very latest plays (409 B.C.), be taken as a standard of comparison, there, at least, is seen the perfection of the third style, the style which is â€˜expressive of characterâ€™; while there is less of visible and masterful art in language, less of Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Î¿Î½, than appears, for example, in the Antigone.

á¼ÎºÎ»á½»ÎµÏ„Î±á½· Î¼ÎµÂ· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 21

Nowhere is the poet's ethical portraiture more delicately Distinctive traits in the diction of the Trachiniae. vivid than in the heroine of the Trachiniae; and a sympathetic reader will feel that the language given to her might well be called á¼ Î¸Î¹ÎºÏ‰Ï„á½±Ï„Î· Î»á½³Î¾Î¹Ï‚. It is exquisitely moulded to the expression of her nature. Take, again, the scene where the Messenger, in Deianeira's presence, taxes Lichas with deceit (vv. 393â€”435). The shades of language most skilfully characterise the three persons,â€”the gentle but resolute lady; the herald, nervously deferential to her, but angrily assertive of his dignity against his humble cross-examiner, the Messenger; and lastly the Messenger himself, with his traits of blunt or familiar speechOne of these traits is notable,â€”the Ï€Î¿á½·Î±Î½ Î´á½¹ÎºÎ·ÏƒÎ¹Î½; (427). This use of Ï€Î¿á¿–Î¿Ï‚, a common colloquialism, occurs in only one other passage of Tragedy, and that is in a late play of Euripides (Helen. 566; 412 B.C.).. In this aspect, then, the Trachiniae shows, like the Philoctetes, the full excellence of the third style,â€”that which is á¼ Î¸Î¹Îºá½½Ï„Î±Ï„Î¿Î½, â€˜most expressive of character.â€™

But the Trachiniae combines this ethical charm of style with a highly elaborate manner in a certain class of passages. Every Greek tragedy contains at least one set speech, á¿¥á¿†ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, of the type usually spoken by a messenger who relates a catastrophe. In such speeches, which were really short excursions of drama into the region of epos, the dramatist was convention ally free to use any measure of rhetorical elaboration, however unsuitable it might be to the person of the speaker; some of the most elaborate á¿¥á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ are delivered by servants. Now, it is a peculiarity of the Trachiniae that, beside two speeches which are normal examples of this class,â€”the speech of Hyllus (vv. 749â€”812), and that of the Nurse (vv. 899â€”946),â€”it contains a remarkable number of other passages which are closely akin to that class. Such are the following short narratives;â€”Lichas recounts the recent deeds of his master (248â€”290); Deianeira relates her meeting with Nessus (531â€”587); and describes the occurrence which rouses her fears concerning the â€˜love-charmâ€™ (672â€”722): such, also, is the great speech of Heracles (1046â€” 1111). Altogether, about one fourth of the play consists of passages which invited or demanded this high elaboration of style, usually reserved for very exceptional moments. It is no accident that the element of narrative in the Trachiniae is so abnormally large; the cause lies in the nature of the fable itself, and is independent of the circumstance that an epic poem, the Capture of Oechalia, was probably one of the chief sources. In narrative or description Sophocles exhibits, as a rule, two characteristics; he is remarkably terse; and he has a bold but artistic originality of phrase, often in a manner which resembles that of Vergil. If the passages just cited from the Trachiniae are compared with their only proper analogues, the set á¿¥á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ of the poet's other plays, it will be felt that, with allowance for differences of degree, the essential quality of style is the same; the greater frequency of it is the distinction of the Trachiniae. This play, like the Philoctetes, is mainly an example of that Sophoclean manner which tradition calls the third or ripest,â€”the manner â€˜best fitted to express character.â€™ But, owing to special causes, it also gives striking prominence to the dominant trait of the poet's â€˜secondâ€™ manner, elaborate and incisive force of phrase,â€”Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¹ÎºÏá½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½±Ï„ÎµÏ‡Î½Î¿Î½. This is a peculiar combination of elements; and it tends to make a reader feel that the style of the Trachiniae is somehow, as a whole, unlike the style found in any one of the other six plays. From that feeling, it has been an easy, but hasty, step to the inference that the manner of this play is unworthy of the master; that it shows the immaturity of youth, or the feebleness of age; or even that it is altogether foreign to him, and must have proceeded from some inferior handSee above, Â§ 1, notes 1, 2, 3..

Î¿á½Îº á¼‚Î½ Î´Î¹Îµá½·Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¼â€™Â· Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á¼¶Î´â€™Â· á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ á¼¦Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 22

The extent to which the Trachiniae shows the influ-Supposed influence of Euripides. ence of Euripides has sometimes been exaggerated. Stress has been laid especially on the form of the prologue; Deianeira opens the play with a speech of some length, in which she incidentally relates certain previous events. But here we must distinguish. The prologue of the Trachiniae is Euripidean only in so far as it is partly historical; it is utterly unlike the typical prologues of Euripides in being dramatic. For, in the first place, Deianeira's speech is no soliloquy,â€”though it is true that she is rather communing with her own thoughts than directly addressing the Nurse; it gives the cue for the Nurse's suggestion that Hyllus should be sent to seek his father, and thus serves to set the drama in motion. Secondly, it is dramatic as illustrating the mind of Deianeira herself,â€”that mind which is to govern the subsequent actionSchlegel's criticism (Â§ 1, n. 3) was the inspiration of a short â€˜programmâ€™ published at Cleve (Prussia) in 1830 by C. M. AxtA. , Commentatio critica qua Trachiniarum Sophocleae prologum subdititium esse demonstratur. Axt uses the term â€˜prologue,â€™ not in the Greek sense (i.e. to denote vv. 1â€”93), but only with reference to Deianeira's speech, vv. 1â€”48. He holds that the play ought to begin at v. 49, with the speech of the Ï„ÏÎ¿Ï†á½¹Ï‚.. Even with regard to this prologue, the inner contrast between the two poets is more significant than the resemblance. Nor can it be said that the general style of the play shows any pervading influence of the supposed kind. There are a few coincidences of phrase between verses of the Trachiniae and verses of Euripides(1) Tr.542(Deianeira speaks,) Ï„Î¿Î¹á½±Î´â€™ á¼©ÏÎ±ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ | Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ¿á½»Ïá¼° á¼€Î½Ï„á½³Ï€ÎµÎ¼ÏˆÎµ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î¼Î±ÎºÏÎ¿á¿¦ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…: cp. Eur. H. F.1373(Megara speaks,) Î¼Î±ÎºÏá½°Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î±Î½Ï„Î»Î¿á¿¦Ïƒâ€™ á¼Î½ Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á¼°ÎºÎ¿Ï…Ïá½·Î±Ï‚. (2) Soph. II. p. 278, assumes that Soph. has borrowed this use of Î³Îµá½»Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ from Eur. : but Soph. had already said in Soph. Ant.1005, á¼Î¼Ï€á½»ÏÏ‰Î½ á¼Î³ÎµÏ…á½¹Î¼Î·Î½.] (4) Soph. Tr.1112á½¦ Ï„Î»á¿†Î¼Î¿Î½ á¼™Î»Î»á½°Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î».: cp. Eur. H. F.877Î¼á½³Î»ÎµÎ¿Ï‚ á¼™Î»Î»á½±Ï‚, á¼ƒ Ï„á½¸Î½ Îµá½ÎµÏÎ³á½³Ï„Î±Î½ | á¼€Ï€Î¿Î²Î±Î»Îµá¿–Ï‚. In Soph. Tr.764Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ¼á¿³ Ï„Îµ Ï‡Î±á½·ÏÏ‰Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î»á¿‡ may, I think, be a reminiscence of Eur. Med.1165(in a similar episode), Î´á½½ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ á½‘Ï€ÎµÏÏ‡Î±á½·ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±. And Soph. Tr.416, Î»á½³Î³), Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹ Ï‡Ïá¿„Î¶ÎµÎ¹Ï‚Â· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î·Î»á½¸Ï‚ Îµá¼¶, is an echo of Aesch. Suppl.567(421 B.C.), Î»á½³Î³), Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹ Î²Î¿á½»Î»ÎµÎ¹Â· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½ ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î·Î»á½¸Ï‚ Îµá¼¶.; but they are trivial; and, even if it were certain that in all of them Sophocles was the debtor, they would merely illustrate a fact which is unquestioned. He was well acquainted with the works of Euripides, and admired them; in his later years, they influenced him in details of language and of versification. But the style of Sophocles, so far as extant work shows, always preserved a thoroughly distinctive character. Certainly the Trachiniae is no exception to that rule; and not merely the style, but the whole mind which appears there, attests the authorship.

Î¸Î±Îºá¿¶Î½ á¼€Ï„Î±ÏÎ²á½´Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¸á½³Î±Ï‚, á½…Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ Î»á½³Î³Î¿Î¹Â· ğŸ—©
Line 23

Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¸á½³Î±Ï‚: for the gen., cp. O. T.885Î”á½·ÎºÎ±Ï‚ á¼€Ï†á½¹Î²Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚.â€”á½…Î´), after á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚, as in Ant.463 f. The drawback to á½ Î´) here is that it would be unduly emphatic: see Ph.87, Appendix.

24 f. These two verses are plainly genuine. It is idle to condemn them merely because they are not indispensable. Nauck, who spares v. 24, rejects v. 25 because Deianeira ought to speak of her fate as depending â€˜on the issue of the combat, not on her beauty.â€™ As if her beauty was not the cause of the combat. It might as well be objected to v. 465, Ï„á½¸ Îºá½±Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Ï„á½¸Î½ Î²á½·Î¿Î½ Î´Î¹á½½Î»ÎµÏƒÎµÎ½, that IolÃ¨ was the victim of war.

á¼Î¾Îµá½»ÏÎ¿Î¹: cp. Ph.287Î³Î±ÏƒÏ„Ïá½¶ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„á½° Ïƒá½»Î¼Ï†Î¿ÏÎ± | Ï„á½¹Î¾Î¿Î½ Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ á¼Î¾Î·á½»ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎºÎµ.

á¼Î³á½¼ Î³á½°Ï á¼¥Î¼Î·Î½ á¼ÎºÏ€ÎµÏ€Î»Î·Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î· Ï†á½¹Î²á¿³

Line 26

Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ á¼€Î³á½½Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚, the supreme arbiter in all trials of strength,â€”as at Argos he was ÏƒÎ¸á½³Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ (Paus. 2. 32 Â§ 7). So Hermes is á¼€Î³á½½Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ ( Pind. Line 29

Ï€ÏÎ¿ÎºÎ·ÏÎ±á½·Î½Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ± (Îºá¿†Ï), feeling anxiety about him, Î¼ÎµÏÎ¹Î¼Î½á¿¶ÏƒÎ± ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï„á½¸ Îºá½³Î±Ï (schol.). The compound occurs only here: Eur. has the simple ÎºÎ·ÏÎ±á½·Î½Ï‰ as = â€˜to be anxiousâ€™ ( Eur. Hipp.223, Eur. H. F.518). Distinguish the other ÎºÎ·ÏÎ±á½·Î½Ï‰, from Îºá½µÏ, â€˜to harmâ€™ ( Aesch. Eum.128, Î´ÏÎ±ÎºÎ±á½·Î½Î·Ï‚ á¼Î¾ÎµÎºá½µÏÎ±Î½Î±Î½ Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚).

Î½á½ºÎ¾ Î³á½°Ï Îµá¼°Ïƒá½±Î³ÎµÎ¹ Îº.Ï„.Î».: â€˜for one night ushers in a trouble, and another, in succession (to the former night), expels it,â€™ â€”to make room for some fresh anxiety. This is a poetical amplification of á¼€Îµá½· Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á¼Îº Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Ï… Ï†á½¹Î²Î¿Î½ Ï„Ïá½³Ï†Ï‰. Each night torments her, as she lies awake, with some new surmise as to her husband's fate.â€” Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ is governed by both verbs.

Î´Î¹Î±Î´ÎµÎ´ÎµÎ³Î¼á½³Î½Î· is used absolutely: its object, if expressed, would have been Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½³ÏÎ±Î½ Î½á½»ÎºÏ„Î±: cp. Her.8. 142á½¡Ï‚ Î´á½² á¼Ï€Î±á½»ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿ Î»á½³Î³Ï‰Î½ á¼ˆÎ»á½³Î¾Î±Î½Î´ÏÎ¿Ï‚, Î´Î¹Î± Î´ÎµÎ¾á½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ (â€˜in their turnâ€™) á¼”Î»ÎµÎ³Î¿Î½ Î¿á¼± á¼€Ï€á½¸ Î£Ï€á½±ÏÏ„Î·Ï‚ á¼„Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î¿Î¹. Thus Î´Î¹Î±Î´ÎµÎ´ÎµÎ³Î¼á½³Î½Î· serves at once (a) to show that the words Î½á½ºÎ¾ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½±Î³ÎµÎ¹ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î½á½ºÎ¾ á¼€Ï€Ï‰Î¸Îµá¿– refer to different nights; and (b) to suggest the new Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Ï‚â€”not expressly mentionedâ€”which the second night brings; since the task in which it is Î´Î¹á½±Î´Î¿Ï‡Î¿Ï‚ to the first is that of harassing the sufferer's mind. See Appendix.

30 ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î½á½ºÎ¾ á¼€Ï€Ï‰Î¸Îµá¿– Î´Î¹Î±Î´ÎµÎ´ÎµÎ³Î¼á½³Î½Î· Ï€á½¹Î½Î¿Î½.

Line 31

Î¿á½“Ï‚ ÎºÎµá¿–Î½á½¹Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ Îº.Ï„.Î». The point of the comparison, which has been prompted by the word ÏƒÏ€Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½, is merely the rarity of the visits. Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³=â€˜at some time or otherâ€™ (cp. á½€Ïˆá½³ Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ, Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³), or perhaps â€˜formerlyâ€™â€”while the labours for Eurystheus were going on: it could not, by itself, mean â€˜only now and then.â€™ The sentence begins as if Ï€Î¿Ï„á½³ were to be followed by some such general phrase as Î´Î¹á½° Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï…:â€”Î¿á½“Ï‚ ÎºÎµá¿–Î½á½¹Ï‚ Ï€Î¿Ï„Îµ...Î´Î¹á½° Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Ï… Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎµá¿–Î´Îµ, â€˜whom he saw only at uncertain intervals.â€™ The interposed simile, however, leads the poet to employ a phrase adapted to the special case of the Î³á¿„Ï„Î·Ï‚,â€”viz., ÏƒÏ€Îµá½·ÏÏ‰Î½ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Îºá¼€Î¾Î±Î¼á¿¶Î½ á¼…Ï€Î±Î¾. The Î³á¿„Ï„Î·Ï‚ sees his distant field only twice a year. But it is not meant that Heracles visits his home just twice a year. Nor has á¼Î¾Î±Î¼á¿¶Î½ any figurative application to him, such as â€˜reaping the joyâ€™ of seeing his children. It is an irrelevant detail. This is quite Homeric. See, e.g., Il.13. 62 ff., where Poseidon, soaring into the air, is likened to a bird which soars Î´Î¹á½½ÎºÎµÎ¹Î½ á½„ÏÎ½ÎµÎ¿Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Î¿: though the sea-god is pursuing no one.

á¼…Ï€Î±Î¾ seems best taken with á¼Î¾Î±Î¼á¿¶Î½ only.

Î³á¿„Ï„Î·Ï‚ á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼„ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏÎ±Î½ á¼”ÎºÏ„Î¿Ï€Î¿Î½ Î»Î±Î²á½½Î½,

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î±á¼°á½¼Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Îºá¼€Îº Î´á½¹Î¼Ï‰Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 34

Î±á¼°á½¼Î½, fortune in life; Ph.179.â€” Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„Îµ Îºá¼€Îº Î´á½¹Î¼Ï‰Î½: this order of words is the most forcible: no sooner did he regain his home, than he had to leave it again. The reversed order (which Brunck prefers) would give greater prominence to his moments of rest.

Ï†ÏÎµÎ½Î¿á¿¦Î½, pres., since the act may be conceived as continuing or re peated; but Ï†Ïá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹, aor., with ref. to the particular utterance: cp. Ph.95á¼Î¾Î±Î¼Î±ÏÏ„Îµá¿–Î½...Î½Î¹Îºá¾¶Î½: ib. 667 f. Î¸Î¹Î³Î³á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½... Î´Î¿á¿¦Î½Î±Î¹.

Îºá¼€Î¼á½² Îº.Ï„.Î». Two constructions are possible: I prefer the first. (1) ÎºÎ±á½·= â€˜and,â€™ depending on Îµá¼°, and the apodosis begins with the direct question, Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». (2) ÎºÎ±á½·=â€˜evenâ€™ (cp. Ant.719 n., Îºá¼€Ï€â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á¿¦), and the apodosis begins with Îºá¼€Î¼á½² Ï‡Ïá½µ. But the first is more deferential; and the very abruptness of Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». is natural here.

Ï†Ïá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï„á½¸ Ïƒá½¹Î½, â€˜to prescribe thy partâ€™ (O.C. 625 n.), i.e., to say what it becomes thee to do. There is only a verbal resemblance to I. A. 1167 (compared by Schneid.), á¼¢ )Î¼á½² Ï‡Ïá½´ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„á½° Ïƒá½±; â€˜am I to make thine answer for thee?â€™â€”The v. l. Ï„á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î½ is weaker, whether taken to mean â€˜so bold a speech,â€™ or (with the schol.) â€˜just thus much.â€™ And the form itself is rare in Sophocles ( Ai.277Î´á½¶Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Ï‚): ib. 185 lyr. Ï„á½¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½).

Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Î´Î¿á½»Î»Î±Î¹Ï‚, Îºá¼€Î¼á½² Ï‡Ïá½´ Ï†Ïá½±ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï„á½¸ Ïƒá½¹Î½Â·
Ï€á¿¶Ï‚ Ï€Î±Î¹Ïƒá½¶ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„Î¿ÏƒÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ Ï€Î»Î·Î¸á½»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚, á¼€Ï„á½°Ï ğŸ—©
Line 54

Ï„Î¿ÏƒÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ´Îµ. Besides Hyllus, the eldest child of Deianeira, legend gave her three other sons, and one daughter (Apoilod. 2. 7 Â§ 8: Diod.4. 37: Paus. 1. 32 Â§ 5). Cp. vv. 1153 ff. For the parataxis (Ï€Î»Î·Î¸á½»ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î¼á½³Î½, á¼€Ï„á½°Ï Î¿á½ Ï€á½³Î¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï‚), cp. O. T.419 n.

55 á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Î¶á½µÏ„Î·ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î¿á½ Ï€á½³Î¼Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î½á½±,

Îµá¼° Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á½¤ÏÎ±Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ â€¦ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Î½: instead of Îµá¼° Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ á½¤ÏÎ±Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€Î±Ï„á½³ÏÎ±...Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Î½. The gen. Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚, placed at the beginning of the clause, illustrates the normal Greek tendency to announce the subject of the statement at the outset (as in Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ Î¿á¼¶ÏƒÎ¸â€™ Îµá¼° Î¶á¿¶Î½ ÎºÏ…ÏÎµá¿–, Ph.444 n.). The second gen., Ï„Î¿á¿¦ â€¦ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Î½, is â€˜epexegetic,â€™ as defining the á½¤ÏÎ±Î½. But it is not in apposition with Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¹Ï‚ (â€˜care for his father,â€”that is, care for his being deemed,â€™ etc.). Rather the two genitives are linked to á½¤ÏÎ±Î½ with slightly different shades of meaning;â€” â€˜care, on his father's account, for his being deemed.â€™ Instead of Ï„Î¿á¿¦ â€¦ Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Î½, we might have had a relative clause, á½…Ï€Ï‰Ï‚ á¼‚Î½...Î´Î¿Îºá¿‡. But, since á½¤ÏÎ±Î½ could take a gen., that constr. was preferred as more compact. Cp. Dem. or. 2 Â§ 4 Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Ï‰Î½ Î¿á½Ï‡á½¶ Î½á¿¦Î½ á½Ïá¿¶ Ï„á½¸Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ (the speaking-time for these things). Î´Î¿ÎºÎµá¿–Î½ here=â€˜be believed to beâ€™: cp. Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Î¹ is better attested than Î½á½³Î¼ÎµÎ¹, and also fitter, as implying the deferential Îµá¼°Îºá½¸Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼´Î·, not the blunt Îµá¼°Îºá½¹Ï‚ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½. See Appendix.

á¼¡Î½á½·Îºâ€™ á¼¢ ÏƒÎµÏƒá½½ÏƒÎ¼ÎµÎ¸Î± â€¦ Î¿á¼°Ï‡á½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼…Î¼Î±. Verses 83 and 85 are probably right as they stand, while v. 84 is spurious. The original form of the interpolation was, however, I think, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼Î¾Î¿Î»Ï‰Î»á½¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚, intended to follow Î¿á¼°Ï‡á½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼…Î¼Î±, in order to supply the condition opposed to ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Ï… Î²á½·Î¿Î½ Ïƒá½½ÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Then it struck a reviser that the passage would be more forcible if ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½ were changed to á¼¢ Ï€á½·Ï€Ï„Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½, and v. 85 were omitted.

This view of the original text may be supported by a consideration which does not seem to have been noticed. The very circumstance which prompted the interpolationâ€”viz., the absence of the condition for Î¿á¼°Ï‡á½¹Î¼ÎµÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼…Î¼Î±â€”is an admirable dramatic touch. For, while Deianeira and her hearers would understand á¼…Î¼Î± as meaning, á¼…Î¼Î± Î¿á¼°Ï‡Î¿Î¼á½³Î½á¿³, her death is really to be linked with his victory.

For a similar piece of textual history, cp. Eur. Î½á¿¦Î½ Î´â€™ á½ Î¾Ï…Î½á½µÎ¸Î·Ï‚ Îº.Ï„.Î». The Î½á¿¦Î½ here, and the Î½á¿¦Î½ in v. 90, are both right: only here we must read Îµá¼´Î± for á¼á¾·, with Vauvilliers. C.265 n. â€˜Even to one who is late, good fortune, if he should ever hear of it, brings gain.â€™ The general sentiment, â€˜better late than never,â€™ is adapted to the particular case. Hyllus is going in search of tidings; and even now, if he hears good tidings, he will have his reward. The words á¼Ï€Îµá½¶ Ï€á½»Î¸Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿ make it clear (I think) that Ï„á½¸ Îµá½– Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½ has here its ordinary sense, â€˜faring well,â€™â€”not the much rarer sense, â€˜acting arightâ€™ (like Ï€Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±Î»á¿¶Ï‚, O. á¼Î¼Ï€Î¿Î»á¾·. Any profitable action may be said, by a metaphor from trading, to â€˜bring inâ€™ gain. Line 94

Î±á¼°á½¹Î»Î±, â€˜gleamingâ€™ with stars: cp. 11: Eur. fr. 596 Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Î´â€™ á½€ÏÏ†Î½Î±á½·Î± | Î½á½ºÎ¾ Î±á¼°Î¿Î»á½¹Ï‡ÏÏ‰Ï‚, á¼„ÎºÏÎ¹Ï„á½¹Ï‚ Ï„â€™ á¼„ÏƒÏ„ÏÏ‰Î½ | á½„Ï‡Î»Î¿Ï‚.â€”á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ¹Î¶Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î± might be merely â€˜slain,â€™ but seems here to have its proper sense, â€˜slain and despoiled.â€™ One point which favours this view has not been noticed. The inverted order of the words (â€˜chiasmusâ€™) has its usual effect for the ear,â€”viz., to indi cate that Ï†Î»Î¿Î³Î¹Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ balances á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ¹Î¶Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î±, as ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÏ…Î½á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ balances Ï„á½·ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ¹. And this is so, if á¼Î½Î±ÏÎ¹Î¶Î¿<*>á½³Î½Î± implies, not only â€˜slain,â€™ but â€˜despoiled,â€™â€”thus serving, with Î±á¼°á½¹Î»Î±, to suggest that bright panoply which Night is still wearing when the Dawn comes to vanquish her,â€”ere the Sun-god has yet issued from her womb. Cp. Aesch. Ag.279Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î½á¿¦Î½ Ï„ÎµÎºÎ¿á½»ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ Ï†á¿¶Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ Îµá½Ï†Ïá½¹Î½Î·Ï‚.

The text has been much suspected (see cr. n.), but without reason. The imagery, indeed, does not form a consistent whole: Night is slain, and then overcomes. But this is merely one of many instances in which the poet's language wavers between the figurative and the literal.

ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÏ…Î½á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹ Ï„Îµ Ï†Î»Î¿Î³Î¹Î¶á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½. The passage is marred by placing the comma, as some do, after Ï„Îµ, and taking the partic. with Î±á¼°Ï„á¿¶. Cp. Porson is cited by Wunder and other editors as the authority for omitting Ï€Î±á¿–Ï‚. á¼¢ Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚ â€¦ ÎºÎ»Î¹Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚. The general sense is simply, â€˜where is he on sea or land?â€™ Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚, rather than Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚ (see cr. n.), is probably right. According to Athenaeus (p. 189 D), Î±á½Î»á½½Î½ is masc. in Attic prose, but fem. in poetry: he quotes Soph. (fr. 503) á¼Ï€Î±ÎºÏ„á½·Î±Ï‚ Î±á½Î»á¿¶Î½Î±Ï‚, and CarcÃ®nus (fr. 1) Î²Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î±Î½ Îµá¼°Ï‚ Î±á½Î»á¿¶Î½Î±. Although, then, Ï€á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹Î¿Ï‚ could be used as an adj. of two terminations, Soph. may have preferred the distinctively fem. form here. In Aesch. P. The constr. is, Ï€á½¹Î¸Î¹ (=Ï€Î¿Ï…) Î½Î±á½·ÎµÎ¹ á¼¢ Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚ Î±á½Î»á¿¶Î½Î±Ï‚ á¼¢ Î´Î¹ÏƒÏ‚. á¼€Ï€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ»Î¹Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚; lit., â€˜where he is situated, either on the sea-straits, or in a resting-place on one of the two continents.â€™ Î½Î±á½·ÎµÎ¹ thus governs an acc. in the first clause, while in the second it stands intransitively with a partic. For a similar difference in form between the clauses after á¼¢

á¼¤, cp. Thuc.4. 5á¼Î½ á½€Î»Î¹Î³Ï‰Ïá½·á¾³ á¼Ï€Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î¿ (Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼ˆÎ¸Î·Î½Î±á½·Î¿Ï…Ï‚), á½¡Ï‚...á¼¢ Î¿á½Ï‡ á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ†á¾¶Ï‚, á¼¢ á¿¥á¾³Î´á½·Ï‰Ï‚ Î»Î·Ïˆá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ Î²á½·á¾³: where the acc. á½‘Ï€Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ (governing ÏƒÏ†á¾¶Ï‚) is better taken as depending on the verb than as absol. For Î½Î±á½·ÎµÎ¹Î½ as=merely â€˜to be in a place,â€™ cp. Soph. O. C.117, Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Î½Î±á½·ÎµÎ¹, said, as here, of a wanderer.

Î´Î¹ÏƒÏ‚. á¼€Ï€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ ÎºÎ»Î¹Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚, lit., â€˜resting uponâ€™ them, as on a support; i.e., having found an abode on land, instead of roaming over sea. The phrase was suggested by the epic use of Îºá½³ÎºÎ»Î¹Î¼Î±Î¹, as said (a) of land which slopes down to the water's edge,â€”thus, as it were, â€˜resting onâ€™ the water; Od.13. 234á¼€ÎºÏ„á½´ | ÎºÎµá¿–Î¸â€™ á¼Î»á½¶ ÎºÎµÎºÎ»Î¹Î¼á½³Î½Î·: (b) of a person who dwells on the edge of water; Il.5. 709Î»á½·Î¼Î½á¿ƒ ÎºÎµÎºÎ»Î¹Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚ ÎšÎ·Ï†Î¹Ïƒá½·Î´Î¹ (where see Leaf): ib. 15. 740 Ï€)á½¹Î½Ï„á¿³ ÎºÎµÎºÎ»Î¹Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹ (the Greeks â€˜leaning onâ€™ the sea): ib. 16. 67 á¿¥Î·Î³Î¼á¿–Î½Î¹ Î¸Î±Î»á½±ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ | ÎºÎµÎºÎ»á½·Î±Ï„Î±Î¹. So in Pind. O. 1. 92 the buried Pelops is described as á¼ˆÎ»Ï†ÎµÎ¿á¿¦ Ï€á½¹Ïá¿³ ÎºÎ»Î¹Î¸Îµá½·Ï‚, â€˜resting byâ€™ (lit. â€˜uponâ€™) â€˜the stream of the Alpheus.â€™ Here, however, Soph. has modified the usage,â€”the dat. denoting land, not water; and the sense is not, dwelling â€˜on the shore ofâ€™ either continent, but simply, anywhere within their limits.

This use of Î´Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ±á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ is possible only because Ï€á½¹Î¸Î¹ precedes. We could not say (e.g.), Î´Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ±á¿–Ï‚ á¼ Ï€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á¼°ÎºÎµá¿–, meaning â€˜he dwells in one of the two continents.â€™ But it is correct to say, Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Î´Î¹ÏƒÏƒÎ±á¿–Ï‚ á¼ Ï€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚ Î¿á¼°ÎºÎµá¿–; meaning, â€˜where in (either of) the two continents is his home?â€™

â€˜The two continentsâ€™ (Europe and Asia, Africa being included in the latter) mean, â€˜the habitable world.â€™ Isocr. or. 4 Â§ 179 Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î³á¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½±ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Ï„á¿· Îºá½¹ÏƒÎ¼á¿³ ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¼á½³Î½Î·Ï‚ Î´á½·Ï‡Î± Ï„ÎµÏ„Î¼Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î·Ï‚, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼ˆÏƒá½·Î±Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î´â€™ Î•á½Ïá½½Ï€Î·Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î»Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î·Ï‚. Varro De Ling. Lat. 4 Ut omnis natura in caelum et terram divisa est, sic caelum in regiones, terra in Asiam et Europam. (Sallust, however, remarks that the division into three continents had been more usual: Jug. 17.ï¼‰

Ï€Î¿Î½Ï„á½·Î±Ï‚ Î±á½Î»á¿¶Î½Î±Ï‚ is merely a general expression for the sea. The phrase was suggested by the Aegaean, with its interfusa nitentes | â€¦ aequora Cycladas (Hor. C. 1. 14. 19). Paley understands:â€”â€˜Is he near home, in the Euripus (Î±á½Î»á¿¶Î½Î±Ï‚), or midway between both continents, i.e., in the Hellespont?â€™ Mr Whitelaw, too, thinks that the Hellespont is meant, and that Î´Î¹ÏƒÏ‚. á¼€Ï€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¹Ï‚=â€˜on a slope looking towards both continents,â€™â€”the sea being regarded as an eminence.

Îµá¼´Ï€â€™, á½¦ ÎºÏÎ±Ï„Î¹ÏƒÏ„Îµá½»Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á½„Î¼Î¼Î±.
Î§Î¿. Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½á¾³ Î³á½°Ï Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á½¶ Ï€Ï…Î½Î¸á½±Î½Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ ğŸ—©

Line 122

á½§Î½, causal gen.: Il.1. 65Îµá½Ï‡Ï‰Î»á¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€Î¹Î¼á½³Î¼Ï†ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹: Thuc.8. 109Î¼á½³Î¼ÏˆÎ·Ï„Î±Î¹...Ï„á¿¶Î½ ...Î³ÎµÎ³ÎµÎ½Î·Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½. The pron. refers back to vv. 103â€”111, which spoke of Deianeira's laments. There is no real obscurity in this, since her grief is the main theme of the ode, and the second strophe (112â€” 121) referred to the fate of Heracles as the cause of that grief.

Hense (whom Nauck follows) thinks that this second antistrophe (122â€”131) requires to be transposed, so as to become the second strophe, immediately following v. 111. But this change is worse than unnecessary. It is liable to the fatal objection that vv. 132 ff. (Î¼á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î³á½°Ï etc.) are then severed from the thought which they develope (vv. 129â€”131 á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï€á¿†Î¼Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡Î±Ïá½° etc.). They are brought into a context which does not suit them (vv. 119â€” 121 á¼€Î»Î»á½± Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ etc.).

á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼„Ï†Î±Ï Î²á½³Î²Î±ÎºÎµ: the subject is each of the preceding nouns, the verb agreeing in number with the nearest ( O. C.8 n.): â€˜but (each) is suddenly gone (from one), while joy, and the loss of it, come to another man in his turn.â€™

Ï„á¿·Î´) is opposed to the Ï„á¿· Î¼á½²Î½ implied in the preceding clause. The text is as clearly sound as the passage itself is beautiful. But numerous changes have been proposed: for these, see Appendix. Here I will only remark that the genuineness of the words ÎºÎ±á½· Î½Î¹Î½â€”which most of the conjectures assume to be corruptâ€”is confirmed by a fragment of the orator Antiphon (no. Line 157

á¼Î³Î³ÎµÎ³ÏÎ±Î¼Î¼á½³Î½Î·Î½ Î¾Ï…Î½Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Î¸), â€˜inscribed with tokens,â€™ i.e., the writing in which Heracles had taken down the oracle (1167). The acc. with the pass. partic. denotes the object of the act. verb (á¼Î³Î³Ïá½±Ï†Ï‰ Î¾Ï…Î½Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± Î´á½³Î»Ï„á¿³): cp. Her.7. 69Î»ÎµÎ¿Î½Ï„á½³Î±Ï‚ á¼Î½Î±Î¼Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹: Xen. An.5. 4. 32á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î³Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î¸á½³Î¼Î¹Î±: Verg. Ecl. 3. 106 inscripti nomina. The word Î¾Ï…Î½Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± recalls the Homeric Ïƒá½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± Î»Ï…Î³Ïá½± ( Il.6. 168),â€”now generally held to denote some kind of alphabetic or syllabic writing (Introd. to Homer, p. 112, n. 1). In later Greek ÏƒÏ…Î½Î¸á½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î± meant a preconcerted cipher: Polyb. 8. 17. 9 ÏƒÏ…Î½Î¸. Î»Î±Î²á½¼Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ¹Ï‚ (â€˜a letter in cipher, and credentialsâ€™): cp. id. 8. 18. 9 ÏƒÏ…Î½Î¸Î·Î¼Î±Ï„Î¹Îºá½° Î³Ïá½±Î¼Î¼Î±Ï„Î±. There is possibly a touch of designed archaism in the poet's phrase; he may have felt that it suited the heroic age to speak of writing as a mystery. This is more likely than that he thought of Heracles as using secret symbols.

Îµá¼¶Ï€Îµ Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ Îµá¼¶Ï€Îµ Î´): epanaphora: O. C.610 n. The Î´á½³Î»Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (157) contained the oracle only. Heracles first expounded this (hence the aor. part. Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±Î¾Î±Ï‚ in 164): then he gave his testamentary directions,â€”not in writing, but merely by word of mouth.

Îµá¼¶Ï€Îµ â€¦ á½… Ï„Î¹ Ï‡ÏÎµá½·Î· Î¼â€™ á¼‘Î»á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î»á½³Ï‡Î¿Ï…Ï‚ ÎºÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎ¹Î½, â€˜he said what I was to take for myself as marriage-property,â€™ i.e., â€˜as my property in right of our marriage.â€™ This means, in accordance with the Attic usage of the poet's age, that she was to take as her own the dowry (Ï€ÏÎ¿á¿–Î¾) which she had brought to her husband, together with any gifts that he might have made to her. Thus a widow is described as á¼€Ï€Î¿Î»Î¹Ï€Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ± Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¿á¼¶ÎºÎ¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¹Î¿ Î±Î¼á½³Î½Î· Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿á¿–ÎºÎ±, [Dem. ] or. 40 Â§ 7. The bride's father (or other representative before the law, Îºá½»ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚) kept a record of the Ï€ÏÎ¿á¿–Î¾, with a view to its recovery at the husband's death, or in the event of a divorce: Isaeus or. 3 Â§ 35 á¼á½°Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î»á½·Ï€á¿ƒ á¼¡ Î³Ï…Î½á½´ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼„Î½Î´ÏÎ±, á¼¢ á¼á½°Î½ á½ á¼€Î½á½´Ï á¼ÎºÏ€á½³Î¼Ïˆá¿ƒ Ï„á½´Î½ Î³Ï…Î½Î±á¿–ÎºÎ±, Î¿á½Îº á¼”Î¾ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï€Ïá½±Î¾Î±ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿· Î´á½¹Î½Ï„Î¹ [i.e. the father, or Îºá½»ÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚] á½ƒ Î¼á½´ á¼Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¹Îºá½¶ Ï„Î¹Î¼á½µÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á¼”Î´Ï‰ÎºÎµÎ½: â€˜which, when he gave it, he did not record at a certain value, as part of the dower.â€™ Thus in [Dem. ] or. 47 Â§ 57 a widow claims some pieces of property on the ground á½…Ï„Î¹ Î±á½‘Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Îµá¼´Î· á¼Î½ Ï„á¿‡ Ï€ÏÎ¿Î¹Îºá½¶ Ï„ÎµÏ„Î¹Î¼Î·Î¼á½³Î½Î±.

á¼£Î½ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ â€¦ Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Î¹: â€˜what share of their father's land he assigned by division to his sons,â€™ i.e., â€˜assigned to them severally.â€™

Î´Î¹Î±Î¹ÏÎµÏ„á½¸Î½: for the verbal adj. of two terminations, cp. O. T.384 n.

Ï‡ÏÎµá½·Î· Î¼â€™ á¼‘Î»á½³ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ ÎºÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Îµá¼¶Ï€Îµ Î´â€™ á¼£Î½ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Î¿Î¹Ï‚

Line 164164-168

The constr. is:

Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±Î¾Î±Ï‚, having first prescribed the time [for the division of the property],

á½¡Ï‚ (saying) that,

á¼¡Î½á½·ÎºÎ± Ï‡á½½ÏÎ±Ï‚ á¼€Ï€Îµá½·Î· Î²ÎµÎ²á½½Ï‚ Ï„Ïá½·Î¼. Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Îºá¼€Î½Î¹Î±á½»Ï‚., when he should have been absent from the country, after his departure, for fifteen months,

Ï„á½¹Ï„Îµ Ï‡ÏÎµá½·Î· ÏƒÏ†Îµ á¼¢ Î¸Î±Î½Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„á¿·Î´Îµ Ï„á¿· Ï‡Ï., á¼¢ â€¦ Î¶á¿†Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». The words Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±Î¾Î±Ï‚ refer to his having expounded the oracle to her before he gave the directions as to his property: á½¡Ï‚ depends on the notion of â€˜sayingâ€™ contained in Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±Î¾Î±Ï‚: and the sentence, á½¡Ï‚, á¼¡Î½á½·ÎºÎ±...á¼€Ï€Îµá½·Î·, Ï‡ÏÎµá½·Î·, explains Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½ Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï„á½±Î¾Î±Ï‚.

I leave the MS. Ï„Ïá½·Î¼Î·Î½Î¿Î½ â€¦ Îºá¼€Î½Î¹Î±á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ unaltered, because it is conceivable that, while Ï„Ïá½·Î¼Î·Î½Î¿Î½ was prompted by the Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½ before it, Îºá¼€Î½Î¹Î±á½»ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ should have been adapted to Î²ÎµÎ²á½½Ï‚. Cp. the personal constr. with Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¹Î¿Ï‚ ( O. á½‘Ï€ÎµÎºÎ´ÏÎ±Î¼á½¹Î½Ï„Î± is lit., â€˜having run out from beneath,â€™ having â€˜eludedâ€™ the imminent danger: Ant.1086Ï„á¿¶Î½ Ïƒá½º Î¸á½±Î»Ï€Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½Ï‡ á½‘Ï€ÎµÎºÎ´ÏÎ±Î¼Îµá¿–. Line 169

Ï„Î¿Î¹Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼”Ï†ÏÎ±Î¶Îµ â€¦ Ï€á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½. Among the various explanations of the gen. Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼©ÏÎ±ÎºÎ»Îµá½·Ï‰Î½ Ï€á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½, two seem better than the rest; and I prefer that which I place first.

(1) It is a gen. of connection, equiv. to the gen. with Ï€ÎµÏá½·, and going with the whole phrase Îµá¼±Î¼Î±ÏÎ¼á½³Î½Î± á¼ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á¾¶ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ rather than with either word alone. â€˜He said that such things were destined to be accomplished in regard to the toils of Heracles.â€™ This is only a rarer and bolder form of the gen. used in poetry after verbs of â€˜speaking aboutâ€™ ( El.317Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î³Î½á½µÏ„Î¿Ï… Ï„á½· Ï†á½µÏ‚;), â€˜asking aboutâ€™ ( Ph.439Ï†Ï‰Ï„á½¸Ï‚ á¼Î¾ÎµÏá½µÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹), â€˜hearing aboutâ€™ ( O. C.307ÎºÎ»á½»Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦). And there is another passage of Sophocles which shows a similarly bold use of it, viz., O. C.355ï¼ˆÎ¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá¿–Î±) á¼ƒ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ á¼Ï‡Ïá½µÏƒÎ¸Î· Ïƒá½½Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚, â€˜the oracles that had been given concerning meâ€™: an example which (to my mind) strongly confirms this view.

(2) It is also possible, though less probable, that the gen. should be taken as partitive with á¼ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á¾¶ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹: destined to be accomplished as part of (in the number of) his toils. For this we might compare such uses of the partitive gen. as Ï€Î»Îµá¿–Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Ïá½½Ï„Î¿Ï… ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î»Î¿Ï… ( Ph.73), á¼Î¾ÎµÏ„á½±Î¶ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿¶Î½ ÏƒÏ…Î³Ï‡Î±Î¹Ïá½¹Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ ( Dem. or. 21 Â§ 202), á¼€ÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Îµá¿–ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¼Î±Îºá½±ÏÏ‰Î½, etc.

(3) Ï€á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ depends on Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¸Îµá¿¶Î½ Îµá¼±Î¼Î±ÏÎ¼á½³Î½Î± as if it were a subst. Îµá¼±Î¼Î±ÏÎ¼á½³Î½Î·Î½:â€” â€˜he said that such a doom for the toils of H. was to be fulfilled.â€™

(4) Ï€á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ depends on á¼ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á¾¶ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ as equiv. to Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏ…Ï„á½´Î½ Î³á½·Î³Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹: â€˜he said that such events were to be accomplished as the end of his toils.â€™ I do not think that the Greek words will bear either of the two latter versions.

á½¡Ï‚ Ï„á½´Î½ Ï€Î±Î»Î±Î¹á½°Î½ Ï†Î·Î³á½¸Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». A note on the Oracle at Dodona, illustrative of this passage and of vv. 1166â€”1168, will be found in the Appendix. The signs were taken from the movement and rustling of the oak's leaves; and these signs were interpreted by the priestesses called Î ÎµÎ»ÎµÎ¹á½±Î´ÎµÏ‚. Cp. fr. 414 Ï„á½°Ï‚ Î¸ÎµÏƒÏ€Î¹á¿³Î´Î¿á½ºÏ‚ á¼±ÎµÏá½·Î±Ï‚ Î”Ï‰Î´Ï‰Î½á½·Î´Î±Ï‚. Euripides spoke of three such priestesses; but Pindar, like Sophocles, gave the number as two (schol. here). In saying that the oak â€˜spakeâ€™ (Î±á½Î´á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹) by their mouths, he follows the established mode of expression with regard to it. See, e.g., Lucian Amor. 31 á¼¡ á¼Î½ Î”Ï‰Î´á½½Î½á¿ƒ Ï†Î·Î³á½¸Ï‚...á¼±ÎµÏá½°Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿ÏÏá½µÎ¾Î±ÏƒÎ± Ï†Ï‰Î½á½µÎ½. Constantine Porphyr. 2. 55 Î”Ï‰Î´á½½Î½Î·, á¼Ï†â€™ á¼§Ï‚ á¼¡ Î´Ïá¿¦Ï‚ á¼¡ Ï†Î¸ÎµÎ³Î³Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î· Ï„á½° Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î´Î±Î¹Î¼á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ Î¼Ï…ÏƒÏ„á½µÏÎ¹Î±.

Others understand:â€”(1) â€˜by the agency of two dovesâ€™: i.e., the signs from the oak were somehow combined with, or explained by, signs derived from birds. (2) â€˜The oak spake from between two dovesâ€™; i.e. a symbolical dove, of stone or metal, stood on either side of the tree. The Appendix will show what can be said for or against each of these theories. Here it may be noted that neither seems to accord so well with the phrase Î±á½Î´á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ á¼Îº. It was through the inspired lips that the utterance of the oak became a â€˜voice.â€™

Line 173

Î½Î±Î¼á½³ÏÏ„ÎµÎ¹Î±: for the Doric form, see on Ant.715 n. Cp. Aesch. Pers.246(dial.) Î½Î±Î¼ÎµÏÏ„á¿† Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ (so Porson for Î½Î·Î¼ÎµÏÏ„á¿†).

Ï„á¿¶Î½Î´Îµ=the predictions (of the alternative issues, prosperity or death): Î½Î±Î¼á½³ÏÏ„ÎµÎ¹Î±=â€˜precision,â€™ i.e. the precise term of fifteen months. ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹=â€˜comes right,â€™ â€˜talliesâ€™ (cp. 1174; and with dat., 1164). Thus the sense is:â€”â€˜The precise term foretold by these prophecies tallies [with the period which has actually elapsed] at the present time,â€™ á½¡Ï‚ (=á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ) Ï„ÎµÎ»ÎµÏƒÎ¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹ Ï‡ÏÎµá½½Î½, â€˜so that they must be fulfilled.â€™ (With Ï‡ÏÎµá½½Î½ we may understand either á¼ÏƒÏ„á½· or Îµá¼¶Î½Î±Î¹: the former is simpler: for the ellipse, cp. Ai.668á¼„ÏÏ‡Î¿Î½Ï„á½³Ï‚ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á½¥ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á½‘Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÎºÏ„á½³Î¿Î½.) The change to á¾§ is needless, and worse.

Others understand:â€”(1) â€˜The true fulfilment of these words as (á½¡Ï‚) they are to be accomplishedâ€™; or (2) â€˜the truth of the prediction that (á½¡Ï‚) these things are to be accomplished.â€™

This is one of those passages in which the manner of Sophocles recalls that of Vergil. The general meaning is simple and clear<*> but a verbal analysis demands the nicest care.

Ï„á½¸ Î³á½°Ï Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». I leave Ï„á½¸ â€¦ Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½ in the text, not feeling certain that it is corrupt; though I am disposed to read, with ThomasE. , Ï„á½° Î³á½°Ï Ï€Î¿Î¸Îµá½·Î½). A discussion of other views will be found in the Appendix. Here I note these points.

(1) If Ï„á½¸ â€¦ Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½ is sound, it means, â€˜the feeling of desireâ€™ in the questioner's mind. It cannot mean â€˜his desireâ€™ in the sense of â€˜that which is desired by himâ€™ (Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿á½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ schol.). This, at least, is the inference from all the evidence available: see nn. on O. C.267 O. C., 1604.

(2) Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½ á¼ÎºÎ¼Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ cannot mean, then, â€˜to learn what is desired.â€™ á¼ÎºÎ¼Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½, if it is to govern Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½, must be explained as having a pregnant sense, á¼ÎºÏ€Î»á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Î¼Î±Î¸á½½Î½, â€˜to satisfy the desire by learning.â€™ Some analogies might be quoted ( Ant.399): but the phrase seems impossibly harsh.

(3) It remains, then, to take Ï„á½¸ Ï€Î¿Î¸Î¿á¿¦Î½ as an acc. of reference: â€˜with regard to his curiosity, wishing to be fully informed.â€™ This is awkward; but it is not inconceivable.

Îµá¼´ÏƒÏ‰=á¼”Î½Î´Î¿Î½, as 867, and oft.; but it properly implies motion (336, 492, 693, 900). The form Îµá¼´ÏƒÏ‰ is here used, as in O. Ant.491 is, however, an exception.

ÏƒÏ„á½³Î³Î·Ï‚ â€¦ Î±á½Î»á¿†Ï‚: the second word here is a mere synonym for the first; hence KvÃ­Äala conjectures Î±á½Ï„á¿†Ï‚: but see n. on O. C.1501.Those â€˜withinâ€™ are her handmaidens; those â€˜without,â€™ the Chorus.

á½„Î¼Î¼Î± Ï†á½µÎ¼Î·Ï‚ Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ, á¼„ÎµÎ»Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ á¼€Î½Î±ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î½: for the fig. sense of á½„Î¼Î¼Î±, cp. O. T.987 n. As said of sunrise, etc., <*>ÏƒÏ‡Ï‰ is more usual than á¼€Î½á½³Ï‡Ï‰: yet cp. Bekk. Anecd. p. 400. 4 á¼€Î½á½³Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½Â· Ï„á½¸ á¼€Î½Î±Ï„á½³Î»Î»ÎµÎ¹Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼¥Î»Î¹Î¿Î½ á¼¢ Ï„á½´Î½ ÏƒÎµÎ»á½µÎ½Î·Î½.

The wording here, á½¡Ï‚ â€¦ á¼€Î½Î±ÏƒÏ‡á½¹Î½, is so suggestive of an acc. abs. ( O. C.380 n.), that it had occurred to me, as to Mr Blaydes, to ask whether Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´Îµ ought not to be Ï„á¿†ÏƒÎ´â€™ á½ƒ: but the answer, I think, is that this would practically make á¼„ÎµÎ»Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ too prominent; the surprise would be more emphasised than the joy.

Î±á¼µ Ï„â€™ á¼ÎºÏ„á½¸Ï‚ Î±á½Î»á¿†Ï‚, á½¡Ï‚ á¼„ÎµÎ»Ï€Ï„Î¿Î½ á½„Î¼Î¼â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶

Î§Î¿. 205 á¼€Î½Î¿Î»Î¿Î»Ï…Î¾á½±Ï„Ï‰ Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼Ï†ÎµÏƒÏ„á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 205205-224

This lively â€˜dance-songâ€™ (á½‘Ï€á½¹ÏÏ‡Î·Î¼Î±) is the direct response of the Chorus to Deianeira's appeal (202 Ï†Ï‰Î½á½µÏƒÎ±Ï„)),â€”expressing their delight at the good news. As Dr. W. Christ, who calls it â€˜a paean to Artemis and Apollo,â€™ justly remarks (Metrik Â§ 443), its contents clearly point to a distribution of the verses between different singers. (1) The first part, down to v. 215 (Îá½»Î¼Ï†Î±Ï‚), is an invitation to song and dance; this would be given either by the coryphaeus, or by the leader of one semichorus. (2) The second part, vv. 216â€”220 (á¼€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¼)...á¼…Î¼Î¹Î»Î»Î±Î½), is the response, delivered by the leader of the other semichorus. (3) Then, at v. 221, the whole Chorus joins in with the refrain of the paean, á¼°á½¼ á¼°á½¼ Î Î±Î¹á½±Î½. (4) The coryphaeus then gives the last three verses, which introduce the next scene.â€”For the metres, see Metrical Analysis.

á¼€Î½Î¿Î»Î¿Î»Ï…Î¾á½±Ï„Ï‰ has been recognised by almost all recent critics and metrists as a certain correction of á¼€Î½Î¿Î»Î¿Î»á½»Î¾ÎµÏ„Îµ (L) or â€Î±Ï„Îµ. But I should keep the MS. Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚, merely reading á¼ for á½ with Erfurdt. The clue to a right interpretation here depends on two points in the context. (1) Deianeira has called for a joyous cry from the women in the house, and from those outside of it (203 f.). The first words of the Chorus accordingly appeal to the women in the house,â€”as is marked, not only by Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚, but by á¼Ï†ÎµÏƒÏ„á½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚, adding that the men of the household are to join in. Then, at v. 210, á½Î¼Î¿á¿¦ Î´á½²...Ï€Î±Î¹á¾¶Î½)...á½¦ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Î¿Î¹, the maidens of the Chorus are invited to raise the paean. (2) The words á¼Î½ Î´á½² ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼€ÏÏƒá½³Î½Ï‰Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». could not have been used unless a reference to women had preceded; it is not enough that it should follow, in á½¦ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Î¿Î¹, at v. 210.

Hence we have to choose between these views, of which I prefer the first. (1) á¼ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï‚, â€˜she whose nuptials are soon to come,â€™ is a poetical phrase for virgo nubilis, and denotes the maidens of the household generally. Nauck, reading Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚...á½ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï‚, gives this sense to it, but admits that the masc. (â€˜quisquis nubilis estâ€™) is awkward: rather it is impossible. (2) á¼ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï‚=â€˜she who is soon to be (re-)united to a husband,â€™ i.e. Deianeira. This is a forcing of the Greek word which can easily be smoothed over in an English paraphrase, but which would probably have seemed very strange to a Greek. (3) Reading Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚ â€¦ á½ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï‚, â€˜the household of maidens,â€™ i.e. â€˜the maidens of the household.â€™ This seems an untenable usage: moreover the metre condemns Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï‚.â€”Another version of this reading, â€˜the house which is soon to receive the husband,â€™ not only strains Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï‚, but fails to supply the necessary antithesis to á¼€ÏÏƒá½³Î½Ï‰Î½.

á¼€Î½Î¿Î»Î¿Î»Ï…Î¾á½±Ï„Ï‰: the á½€Î»Î¿Î»Ï…Î³á½µ or á½€Î»Î¿Î»Ï…Î³Î¼á½¹Ï‚ was a cry to the gods, usually expressive of joy or hope, in prayer or sacrifice: and it is especially said of women (e.g. Il.6. 301, Od.3. 450: Aesch. Theb.268 etc.). But this verb denotes a cry of horror in Soph. El.750.

Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚, rather â€˜for the houseâ€™ (dat. of interest) than merely â€˜in itâ€™; cp. Aesch. Ag.27Î´á½¹Î¼Î¿Î¹Ï‚ | á½€Î»Î¿Î»Ï…Î³Î¼á½¸Î½ Îµá½Ï†Î·Î¼Î¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± Ï„á¿‡Î´Îµ Î»Î±Î¼Ï€á½±Î´Î¹ | á¼Ï€Î¿ÏÎ¸Î¹á½±Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½.â€”á¼€Î»Î±Î»Î±Î³Î±á¿–Ï‚, probably due to Triclinius, has been received instead of á¼€Î»Î±Î»Î±á¿–Ï‚ by many recent edd., in order that the first foot of the verse may be a tribrach (see Analysis Metr.). á¼€Î»Î±Î»á½µ was the more frequent form; but the other occurs as a v. l. in Eur. Phoen.335, as á¼€Î»Î±Î»Î±Î»Î±á½· is a v. l. for á¼€Î»Î±Î»Î±á½· in Ar. Av.1761: and a loss of Î±Î» or Î±Î³ would of course have been easy. The á¼€Î»Î±Î»á½µ was a cry of triumph ( Soph. Ant.133 n.).

á¼€Î»Î±Î»Î±Î³Î±á¿–Ï‚ á¼ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î»á½¹Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ï‚, á¼Î½ Î´á½²
ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼€ÏÏƒá½³Î½Ï‰Î½ á¼´Ï„Ï‰ ğŸ—©
Line 207

ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚, fem.: cp. O. C.751 n. â€”The acc. Ï„á½¸Î½ Îµá½Ï†. á¼ˆÏ€. depends on á¼´Ï„Ï‰ ÎºÎ»Î±Î³Î³á½° as=á½‘Î¼Î½Îµá½·Ï„Ï‰: cp. El.123Ï„á½±ÎºÎµÎ¹Ï‚ ...Î¿á¼°Î¼Ï‰Î³á½°Î½ | ...á¼ˆÎ³Î±Î¼á½³Î¼Î½Î¿Î½Î±: ib. 556 Îµá¼° Î´á½³ Î¼â€™ á½¦Î´â€™ á¼€Îµá½¶ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…Ï‚ | á¼Î¾á¿†ÏÏ‡ÎµÏ‚.â€”á¼ˆÏ€á½¹Î»Î»Ï‰, the shorter form of the acc., as in O. C.1091(lyr.): like Î Î¿ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î´á¿¶, it was used chiefly after Î½á½´ Ï„á½¸Î½, Î¼á½° Ï„á½¸Î½.â€”Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î±Î½: cp. El.637Î¦Î¿á¿–Î²Îµ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Îµ,â€”with reference to his image being placed in front of houses. Paus. (1. 44. 2) saw at Megara a hieron of Apollo Î ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„á½µÏÎ¹Î¿Ï‚. C. O. MÃ¼ller (Dorians bk II. ch. 2 Â§ 6) points out that the title Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ„á½±Ï„Î·Ï‚ was given to Apollo in the Ionian colonies of Miletus, on the shores of Pontus. Line 213

á¼ŒÏÏ„ÎµÎ¼Î¹Î½ á½ˆÏÏ„Ï…Î³á½·Î±Î½. The epithet was usu. understood as meaning â€˜born in Ortygia.â€™ That name, like Nysa, was associated with various places (as Syracuse; Aetolia, schol. Apoll. Rh. 1. 419; Ephesus, Strabo 14. 639); but most frequently with Delos, as a name either for that island itself, or for some islet near it (Rheneia?): cp. Hom. h. Apoll. 16, which describes Artemis and Apollo as born, Ï„á½´Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Î½ á½ˆÏÏ„Ï…Î³á½·á¿ƒ, Ï„á½¸Î½ Î´á½² ÎºÏÎ±Î½Î±á¿‡ á¼Î½á½¶ Î”á½µÎ»á¿³. The epithet is parodied by Ar. Av.870Î›Î·Ï„Î¿á¿– á½€ÏÏ„Ï…Î³Î¿Î¼á½µÏ„Ïá¾³ (â€˜Quail motherâ€™) Asteria, Leto's sister, was said to have escaped from Zeus by taking the form of a quail (á½„ÏÏ„Ï…Î¾): Apollod.1. 2Â§ 2. One theory explains the name Ortygia as simply â€˜abounding with quailsâ€™; another (Preller vol. I. p. 238) supposes that the á½„ÏÏ„Ï…Î¾ was taken as the type of a good mother; but the question remains uncertain.

Artemis was worshipped on the coasts near Malis (637 n.), but we have no proof that the name á½ˆÏÏ„Ï…Î³á½·Î± was specially given to her there. Perhaps the poet uses it here merely as one of her standing epithets.

á¼€Îµá½·ÏÎ¿Î¼). Homeric verse admits the elision of Î±Î¹ in the verbal endings â€Î¼Î±Î¹, â€ÏƒÎ±Î¹ (except in the infin.), â€Ï„Î±Î¹, â€ÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. á¼°Î´Î¿á½» Î¼): this Î¼) must depend on á¼°Î´Î¿á½»: that after Îµá½Î¿á¿– depends on á¼€Î½Î±Ï„Î±Ïá½±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ¹, the shriek being here literally an â€˜interjection.â€™

á½ ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒá½¹Ï‚: the ivy was sacred to Dionysus, who is styled ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎµá½»Ï‚ (Paus. 1. 31 Â§ 6), ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï†á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚, ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï‡Î±á½·Ï„Î·Ï‚, etc.: cp. Here, however, the Trachinian maidens imagine themselves to be bacchanals; the music of the Î±á½Î»á½¹Ï‚ suggests the spell of the ÎºÎ¹ÏƒÏƒá½¹Ï‚: and they speak as if the ivy on their brows was sending its mystic power through their whole frames, stirring them to the dance. Just so the laurel was the symbol of poetical inspiration.

ÎºÎ±Ï„â€™ á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Ï… ÎºÏ„á¿†ÏƒÎ¹Î½. á¼ƒ Ï€Ïá¿¶Ï„Î± Î²Î¿á½»Î»Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹, sc. Î´Î¹Î´á½±ÏƒÎºÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹. á¼”Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï€Î¿Î½: 76 n.â€”In the sequel, Deianeira dies before Heracles is brought home. The answer of Lichas is unconsciously evasive; it is also undesignedly suggestive of a contrast between the hero's present state, and that in which he is to arrive, Î½á½¹Ïƒá¿³ Î²Î±Ïá½»Ï‚.â€”á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î¿Î½Ï„á½± Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„Î±. 's question; and the double copula, Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½·, links á¼°ÏƒÏ‡á½»Î¿Î½Ï„Î± with it more closely than the following words are linked by the simple ÎºÎ±á½·. Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Î³á¿†Ï‚ (á¼”Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï€ÎµÏ‚), (Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ) Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î±Ï‚ Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ Î²Î±ÏÎ²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï… (á¼”Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï€ÎµÏ‚ï¼‰; where did you leave him,â€”whether it was in Greece or abroad that you left him? Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ, either doubled or single, is thus used, with ellipse of the verb, when a statement or a question is to include two alternative suppositions: cp. Legg. 844 D á½ƒÏ‚ á¼‚Î½ á¼€Î³ÏÎ¿á½·ÎºÎ¿Ï… á½€Ï€á½½ÏÎ±Ï‚ Î³Îµá½»ÏƒÎ·Ï„Î±Î¹, Î²Î¿Ï„Ïá½»Ï‰Î½ Îµá¼µÏ„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½»ÎºÏ‰Î½ [sc. á¼Î³Îµá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿],...Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï‡Ï‰Ïá½·Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î½ á¼„Î»Î»Ï‰Î½,...Ï€ÎµÎ½Ï„á½µÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± á½€Ï†ÎµÎ¹Î»á½³Ï„Ï‰ Î´ÏÎ±Ï‡Î¼á½±Ï‚. So, with a single Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ, O. T.517: with doubled Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ, ib. 194 O. T., 1049.In such sentences Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ becomes practically equivalent to á¼¤. But it cannot, of course, replace á¼¤ in a direct statement or question: i.e., â€˜This is either good or bad,â€™ could not be rendered, Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿ Îµá¼´Ï„â€™ á¼€Î³Î±Î¸á½¸Î½ Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ ÎºÎ±Îºá½¹Î½ á¼ÏƒÏ„Î¹. Hence the following punctuation, adopted by Dindorf, is impossible:

Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Î³á¿†Ï‚; Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î±Ï‚ Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ Î²Î±ÏÎ²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï…; Î»á½³Î³Îµ. This would require á¼¢ instead of Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ. (Paley, who follows Dindorf, seems to have felt a misgiving; â€˜The use of Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ for á¼¢,â€™ he says, â€˜is remarkable.â€™ï¼‰â€”Ellendt prefers a third way of pointing, which L (see cr. n.) also suggests:

Ï€Î¿á¿¦ Î³á¿†Ï‚; Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î±Ï‚ Îµá¼´Ï„Îµ Î²Î±ÏÎ²á½±ÏÎ¿Ï…, Î»á½³Î³Îµ (â€˜say whether...â€™). The objection to this is that it throws too much emphasis on the distinction between Greek and foreign soil.

Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá¿´Î±Ï‚ (Î³á¿†Ï‚)=Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½·Î´Î¿Ï‚ (as in O. C.1292 etc.), i.e. Hellas, as the land of his ancestors (not as â€˜the land of his father Zeusâ€™). Cp. 1060 Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ á¼™Î»Î»á½°Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼„Î³Î»Ï‰ÏƒÏƒÎ¿Ï‚. The rumours reported by Hyllus spoke of Heracles as freed from OmphalÃ¨, but left it doubtful whether he was yet in Euboea (69â€”75).

Î›á½·. á¼€ÎºÏ„á½µ Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼”ÏƒÏ„â€™ Î•á½Î²Î¿Î¹á½·Ï‚, á¼”Î½Î¸â€™ á½Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ ğŸ—©
Line 237

Î•á½Î²Î¿á½·Ï‚: 74 n. The northwestern extremity of Euboea is a small peninsula, which runs out westward just opposite the mouth of the Malian Gulf. It ends in the promontory once called Îšá½µÎ½Î±Î¹Î¿Î½, and now Cape LithÃ¡da. Zeus Îšá½µÎ½Î±Î¹Î¿Ï‚ was worshipped on the neighbouring hill-tops (upwards of 2800 ft. in height), as on so many other summits (cp. Ph.1040 n.): Aesch. fr. 29 Î•á½Î²Î¿á¿–Î´Î± Îºá½±Î¼Ï€Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†á½¶ ÎšÎ·Î½Î±á½·Î¿Ï… Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ | á¼€ÎºÏ„á½µÎ½. The legendary Oechalia, which Heracles sacked, was not near Cenaeum, but some 50 miles S. E. of it, in the territory of Eretria (Hecataeus ap. Paus.4. 2. 3: Strabo 10 p. 448). Sophocles shows his knowledge of this tradition by his reference to the hero's march from Oechalia to Cenaeum (750 Îµá¼·ÏÏ€Îµ).

á½Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Î²Ï‰Î¼Î¿á½ºÏ‚: the verb denotes properly the act of tracing the temenos in which the altars were to stand. Cp. Her.3. 142Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚...Î²Ï‰Î¼á½¸Î½ á¼±Î´Ïá½»ÏƒÎ±Ï„Î¿ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ Ï€ÎµÏá½¶ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ Î¿á½”ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎµ. In v. 754 the act. á½Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹ is used: the midd. occurs in Xen. An.7. 5. 13ÏƒÏ„á½µÎ»Î±Ï‚ á½ÏÎ¹Ïƒá½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹. The plur. Î²Ï‰Î¼Î¿á½ºÏ‚ (as in 754, 993) might be used of a single altar (cp. Ant.1006), but here prob. denotes several,â€”the sacrifice being on so great a scale (760 ff.).

Ï„á½³Î»Î· Ï„â€™ á¼”Î³ÎºÎ±ÏÏ€Î±, tributes (or dues) of fruits; i.e., the revenues derived from a temenos containing fruit-trees or capable of yielding crops. The poet can say, á½ Ïá½·Î¶ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ Ï„á½³Î»Î· á¼”Î³ÎºÎ±ÏÏ€Î±, because he is thinking of the temenos itself (cp. 754). Such lands were sometimes cultivated under the direct control of the priests; sometimes they were let to tenants: cp. Plat. á¼¡Î¼ÎµÏá¿¶Î½ goes with á¼€Î½á½µÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î¿Î½, not with Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½: â€˜without number of days,â€™=â€˜extending to countless days.â€™ Cp. Ai.601 f. Î¼Î·Î½á¿¶Î½ | á¼€Î½á½µÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î¿Ï‚: O. C.677 n.

The form á¼€Î½á½µÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î¿Ï‚ is of a frequent type. When the second part of a compound adj. has a disyllabic stem (usu. a verbal stem), beginning with a short vowel, this vowel may be lengthened. Such forms were oft. convenient in poetry (as á¼€Î½á½µÏÎ¿Ï„Î¿Ï‚, Îµá½á½µÎ½ÎµÎ¼Î¿Ï‚, Ï†Î¹Î»á½µÏÎµÏ„Î¼Î¿Ï‚), but many of them were equally current in good prose (as á¼€Î½á½µÎºÎµÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚, á¼€Î½á½µÎ½Ï…Ï„Î¿Ï‚, á¼€Î½Î·Î»Îµá¿¶Ï‚, Îµá½á½½Î½Ï…Î¼Î¿Ï‚). The restriction of á¼€Î½á½µÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î¿Ï‚ to classical poetry and late prose (as Athen. p. 253 F) is not due to 1ts form, but to the fact that classical prose preferred á¼€Î½Î±Ïá½·Î¸Î¼Î·Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Tragedy uses á¼€Î½á½±ÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î¿Ï‚ (Î±^) where it suits the metre (as in El.225). In Theocr. 15. 45 á¼€Î½á½±ÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î¿Î¹ (Î±â€”) is Doric for á¼€Î½á½µÏÎ¹Î¸Î¼Î¿Î¹.

Ï€Ïá½±ÎºÏ„Ï‰Ï Ï†Î±Î½á¿‡: cp. 862: for á½…Ï„Î¿Ï… without á¼„Î½, cp. O. T.1231 n. The agency of Zeus is explained below O. T., 274 ff.

ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Ï‚ Î´á½²: Î´á½² resumes the story after the parenthetic apology (Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï…... Ï†Î±Î½á¿‡): cp. ÎºÎµá¿–Î½Î¿Î¹ Î´) in 281. Wunder rejects these two verses, (1) because they repeat the substance of vv. 248â€”250, and (2) because Lichas ought not to pain his mistress by mentioning OmphalÃ¨. But (1) these vv. explain á¼Î½ Î›Ï…Î´Î¿á¿–Ï‚, and define Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½Î¿Î½: (2) the herald's motive for silence concerning IolÃ¨ does not apply to the case of OmphalÃ¨. Hyllus had already mentioned â€˜the Lydian womanâ€™ to his mother (70).

Ï€ÏÎ±Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚ â€¦ á½ˆÎ¼Ï†á½±Î»á¿ƒ. Hermes, by command of Zeus, took Heracles to Lydia, and sold him in the slave-market to OmphalÃ¨: the price was paid to Eurytus, as a Ï€Î¿Î¹Î½á½µ for the murder of Iphitus ( Apollod.2. 6. 2).

Two tragic poets of the fifth century B.C., Ionof Chios and Achaeus, had written an á½ˆÎ¼Ï†á½±Î»Î· ÏƒÎ±Ï„Ï…ÏÎ¹Îºá½µ. Two poets of the Middle Comedy, Antiphanes (Athen. 112 C) and Cratinus jun. (id. 669 B) wrote an á½ˆÎ¼Ï†á½±Î»Î·, picturing Heracles abandoned to sensuous pleasures. Itis the more noteworthy how Sophocles, in lightly touching on this episode, has guarded his hero's dignity. For he speaks only of servile labours for the Lydian taskmistress (70 It, 356); and marks how the bondsman felt his disgrace (254).

á¼Î½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼Î¾á½³Ï€Î»Î·ÏƒÎµÎ½, á½¡Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹. ğŸ—©
Line 253

á¼Î½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„á½¸Î½. The popular version spoke of three years. This was the term assigned by the mythographer Herodorus (c. 430 B.C.?), acc. to the schol.; as it is by Apollodorus (2. 6. 2). If this change was due to Sophocles, we can see the artistic motive. Three months or so, after the bondage, were required for the war in Euboea. If the poet had made Heracles go to Lydia 39, instead of 15, months before his death, there would have been less room for those hopes which contend with fears in the opening scene of the Trachiniae.

No emendation is probable. Nauck's Î±á½Ï„á½¹Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ± would be possible only if Eurytus had himself sent Heracles into slavery.

á¼¦ Î¼á½´Î½ Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÏ„á¿†ÏÎ± Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´Îµ Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€á½±Î¸Î¿Ï…Ï‚

This may be parallel: there is nothing, however, to show that the sing. cannot there be taken literally. For the collective sing., cp. Aesch. Theb.197á¼€Î½á½´Ï Î³Ï…Î½á½µ Ï„Îµ Ï‡á½¥ Ï„Î¹ Ï„á¿¶Î½ Î¼ÎµÏ„Î±á½·Ï‡Î¼Î¹Î¿Î½.â€” Î´Î¿Ï…Î»á½½ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½: the prose word, in ref. to prisoners of war, was not Î´Î¿Ï…Î»Î¿á¿¦Î½, but á¼€Î½Î´ÏÎ±Ï€Î¿Î´á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½: hence Thuc.8. 28Ï„á½° á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½±Ï€Î¿Î´Î± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î´Î¿á¿¦Î»Î± ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Î»Îµá½»Î¸ÎµÏÎ± (referring to their previous condition).

ÎºÎ¿á½Ï‡ á¼¡Î»á½·Ï‰ÏƒÎµ Ï„Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Ï‚, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½…Î¸â€™ á¼Î³Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼¦Î½, ğŸ—©

ÎºÎ¿á½Ï‡ á¼¡Î»á½·Ï‰ÏƒÎµ Ï„Î¿á½”Ï€Î¿Ï‚: modelled on the Homeric Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼Î»á½·Ï‰ÏƒÎµ Î²á½³Î»Î¿Ï‚ ( Il.16. 737), with a reminiscence also of Î¿á½Î´â€™ á¼…Î»Î¹Î¿Î½ á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï‚ á¼”ÏƒÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ (ib. 24. 92).

á½…Î¸â€™ á¼Î³Î½á½¸Ï‚ á¼¦Î½. The Homeric poems know nothing of a ritual for purification from homicide: the blood-shedder either flies into exile ( Il.24. 480 ff.), or prevails on the kinsfolk of the slain to accept a Ï€Î¿Î¹Î½á½µ (ib. 9. 632 ff.), and stays at home. Here the schol. supposes that, by á¼Î³Î½á½¹Ï‚, Sophocles alludes simply to the year of exile having expired. This may be so; but it is more probable that Heracles is conceived as also undergoing a formal Îºá½±Î¸Î±ÏÏƒÎ¹Ï‚. According to other writers, he received this from Deiphobus at Amyclae, after vainly seeking it from Neleus at Pylos ( Apollod.2. 6. 2: Diod.4. 31). So Aesch. makes the exile Orestes receive the ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±ÏÎ¼Î¿á½¶ Ï‡Î¿Î¹ÏÎ¿ÎºÏ„á½¹Î½Î¿Î¹ ( Aesch. Eum.283Aesch. Eum., 449). The homicide who withdrew into banishment was said á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„á½·Î¶ÎµÎ¹Î½ (or á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„Îµá¿–Î½),â€”a word not always restricted to one year: Legg. 868 D á¼Î½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Ï„ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚ á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„Îµá¿–Î½. Cp. ib. E ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±á½·ÏÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î¼á½²Î½ Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î±á½Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±ÏÎ¼Î¿á½»Ï‚, Ï„ÏÎ¹ÎµÏ„Îµá¿–Ï‚ Î´á½² á¼€Ï€ÎµÎ½Î¹Î±Ï…Ï„á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î±Ï„ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½. ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„á½¸Î½ â€¦ á¼Ï€Î±ÎºÏ„á½¸Î½: the adj. here merely=Î¾á½³Î½Î¿Î½, â€˜alien,â€™ i.e., not belonging to his own home. á¼Ï€Î±ÎºÏ„á½¹Ï‚ is prop. said of allies, or mercenaries, whom a foreign state calls in (á¼Ï€á½±Î³ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹) to its aid: cp. á¼Ï€ÎµÏÏá½¹Î¸Î·ÏƒÎµ, Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î´â€™ á¼€Ï„Î·Ïá¾· Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á½·, ğŸ—©
Line 264

á¼Ï€ÎµÏÏá½¹Î¸Î·ÏƒÎµ. This verb can denote the blended sound of many voices ( Aesch. Ch.458); esp., the responsive shout of a crowd ( Eur. Hec.553, Eur. Or.901). Here it refers to loud and vehement railing: cp. Soph. Ant.259Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹...á¼ÏÏá½¹Î¸Î¿Ï…Î½ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á½· (n.), and ib. 413 á¼Ï€Î¹ÏÏá½¹Î¸Î¿Î¹Ï‚ | ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½.

From á¼Ï€ÎµÏÏá½¹Î¸Î·ÏƒÎµ a verb of more general sense, such as á½•Î²ÏÎ¹ÏƒÎµ, is to be supplied with á¼€Ï„Î·Ïá¾· Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á½·. (For the sense of á¼€Ï„Î·Ïá¾·, cp. Ph.1272: Paley wrongly takes it as= â€˜deluded.â€™) This is the easier, since the antithesis between Î³á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ and Ï†ÏÎµÎ½á½· at once suggests a distinction between affronts expressed in speech and those which showed the malicious intention in another way, viz., by acts: two examples of the verbal insults are given, and then one of the other kind (Î´Îµá½·Ï€Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´) Îº.Ï„.Î».). Instances of zeugma quite as bold occur elsewhere in poetry; for the Greek mind was quick to seize the hint of a contrast, and did not always require full expression of it: e.g., Od.15. 374á¼Îº Î´â€™ á¼„ÏÎ± Î´ÎµÏƒÏ€Î¿á½·Î½Î·Ï‚ Î¿á½ Î¼Îµá½·Î»Î¹Ï‡Î¿Î½ á¼”ÏƒÏ„Î¹Î½ á¼€ÎºÎ¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ±Î¹ | Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼”Ï€Î¿Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Ï„Î¹ á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ (sc. Ï€Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Î½): ib. 20. 312 f. Î¼á½µÎ»Ï‰Î½ ÏƒÏ†Î±Î¶Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Ï‰Î½ Î¿á¼´Î½Î¿Î¹á½¹ Ï„Îµ Ï€Î¹Î½Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Î¿ | ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ïƒá½·Ï„Î¿Ï… (sc. á¼ÏƒÎ¸Î¹Î¿Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï…). In these examples, just as here, the antithesis of nouns supersedes an explicit antithesis of verbs.

Others understand :â€”â€˜railed against him both with (rude) words and with evil intent.â€™ To this there are two objections. (1) Since all the supposed affronts are then verbal, the antithesis would require an epithet for Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î¹Ï‚ (such as Î±á¼°ÏƒÏ‡ÏÎ¿á¿–Ï‚), to balance á¼€Ï„Î·Ïá¾·. (2) The formula Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î¼á½²Î½ â€¦ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î´á½³ would be out of place, unless two classes of verbal taunts were distinguished by the presence or absence of a spiteful intent; but the context excludes such a distinction.

The text is clearly (I think) sound. It is unwarrantable, as it is undesirable, to strike out Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î´â€™ â€¦ Ï‡ÎµÏÎ¿á¿–Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ (see cr. n.). Again, it is improbable that a verse has been lost after v. 264.

Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½§Î½ Ï„á½³ÎºÎ½Ï‰Î½: the sons were four in number, acc. to Hesiod (fr. 70, ap. schol. here),â€” Î”Î·á½·Ï‰Î½, ÎšÎ»á½»Ï„Î¹Î¿Ï‚, Î¤Î¿Î¾Îµá½»Ï‚, á¼¼Ï†Î¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚. Î»Îµá½·Ï€Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿: cp. Thuc.6. 72á¼€Î½á½´Ï ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á¼„Î»Î»Î± Î¾á½»Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î¿á½Î´ÎµÎ½á½¸Ï‚ Î»ÎµÎ¹Ï€á½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚.â€”Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á½¹Î¾Î¿Ï… ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Î½: for the prep., cp. Soph. By Ï„á½¹Î¾Î¿Ï… ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ is meant a trial (of the competitors) which the bow decides. ÎºÏá½·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ thus almost =á¼€Î³á½½Î½: cp. Soph. Ph.1050 n. There was a legend that Eurytus offered the hand of his daughter IolÃ¨ as a prize for the man who should surpass him and his sons in archery. Heracles conquered, but Eurytus broke his promise (schol.: Apoll. 2. 6. 1).â€”Eurytus, like his father Melaneus, was a great archer. In Hom. Od.8. 226 ff. he challenges Apollo, and is slain by him. The bow of Eurytus, inherited by Iphitus, was given by the latter to Odysseus (ib. 21. 31 ff.).

á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ â€¦ á¼Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸á½³ÏÎ¿Ï… with Î´Î¿á¿¦Î»Î¿Ï‚ (not with á¿¥Î±á½·Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿, as gen. of agent, like Ï€Î»Î·Î³Îµá½¶Ï‚ Î¸Ï…Î³Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ á¼Î¼á¿†Ï‚, Eur. Or.497): á¼Î»ÎµÏ…Î¸á½³ÏÎ¿Ï… serves merely to emphasise Î´Î¿á¿¦Î»Î¿Ï‚ by contrast.

á¾ Î½Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚, Heracles. Cp. Eur. Alc.756(of Heracles) Ï€Î¿Ï„á¿†ÏÎ± Î´â€™ á¼Î½ Ï‡Îµá½·ÏÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹ Îºá½·ÏƒÏƒÎ¹Î½Î¿Î½ Î»Î±Î²á½¼Î½ | Ï€á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î±á½·Î½Î·Ï‚ Î¼Î·Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚ Îµá½”Î¶Ï‰ÏÎ¿Î½ Î¼á½³Î¸Ï…, | á¼•Ï‰Ï‚ á¼Î¸á½³ÏÎ¼Î·Î½â€™ Î±á½Ï„á½¸Î½ á¼€Î¼Ï†Î¹Î²á¾¶ÏƒÎ± Ï†Î»á½¸Î¾ | Î¿á¼´Î½Î¿Ï…Â· ÏƒÏ„á½³Ï†ÎµÎ¹ Î´á½² ÎºÏá¾¶Ï„Î± Î¼Ï…ÏÏƒá½·Î½Î·Ï‚ ÎºÎ»á½±Î´Î¿Î¹Ï‚ | á¼„Î¼Î¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™ á½‘Î»Î±ÎºÏ„á¿¶Î½. The á¼€Ï„Î·Ïá½° Ï†Ïá½µÎ½ (264) of Eurytus seized this opportunity of inflicting an insult.

á¼”ÏÏÎ¹ÏˆÎµÎ½ á¼ÎºÏ„á½¸Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½. A Greek vase, found in Sicily, quaintly illustrates some such incident. The inebriated Heracles is lying on his back outside a closed door, from above which an old woman is pouring cold water upon him. Satyrs and maenads appear at each side of the group. (Benndorf, Gr. und Sicilische Vasenbilder pl. 44.) I am indebted for this reference to Mr MurrayS. , of the British Museum.

á½§Î½ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Ï‡á½¹Î»Î¿Î½: for the causal gen. cp. Ph.327 n.

á¿¥Î±á½·Î¿Î¹Ï„Î¿Â· Î´Îµá½·Ï€Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼¡Î½á½·Îºâ€™ á¼¦Î½ á¾ Î½Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚,
á¼”ÏÏÎ¹ÏˆÎµÎ½ á¼ÎºÏ„á½¸Ï‚ Î±á½Ï„á½¹Î½. á½§Î½ á¼”Ï‡Ï‰Î½ Ï‡á½¹Î»Î¿Î½,
270 á½¡Ï‚ á¼µÎºÎµÏ„â€™ Î±á½–Î¸Î¹Ï‚ á¼¼Ï†Î¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î¤Î¹ÏÏ…Î½Î¸á½·Î±Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 270

Î±á½–Î¸Î¹Ï‚, at a later time: Ant.1204 n.

Î¤Î¹ÏÏ…Î½Î¸á½·Î±Î½ â€¦ ÎºÎ»Î¹Ï„á½»Î½. We cannot be sure that Sophocles had any clear picture of the place before his mind; but his phrase, at least, is not unsuitable. ÎºÎ»Î¹Ï„á½»Ï‚, â€˜slope,â€™ does not necessarily imply great elevation. The site of Tiryns is a ridge of limestone rock on the Argolic Gulf (cp. 1151), in which, at some prehistoric time, it formed an island. The length of this ridge, from N. to S. , is about 328 yards: its width about 109. The upper citadel of Tiryns was at the southern end, where the rock attains a height of about 72 feet above sea-level, and of 59 feet above the present surface of the plain. North of this was the lower citadel; and the whole was surrounded by those massive â€˜Cyclopeanâ€™ walls from which Tiryns derived its Homeric epithet ( Il.2. 559), Ï„ÎµÎ¹Ï‡Î¹á½¹ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ±. See Schliemann's Tiryns, p. 177. Such a site, though not steep or lofty, might correctly be described as the Î¤Î¹ÏÏ…Î½Î¸á½·Î± ÎºÎ»Î¹Ï„á½»Ï‚.â€”For the Ï…^ in ÎºÎ»Î¹Ï„á½»Î½, cp. Ant.1144 n., and ib. 1127 Î»Î¹Î³Î½á½»Ï‚: so Î½Î·Î´á½»Ï‚ ( Eur. Andr.356 etc.).

á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´Î±Ï‚: acc. to Od.21. 22, Iphitus came, á¼µÏ€Ï€Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î´Î¹Î¶á½µÎ¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚, Î±á¼µ Î¿á¼± á½„Î»Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿ | Î´á½½Î´ÎµÎºÎ± Î¸á½µÎ»ÎµÎ¹Î±Î¹, á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î´â€™ á¼¡Î¼á½·Î¿Î½Î¿Î¹ Ï„Î±Î»Î±ÎµÏÎ³Î¿á½·: but Apollod.2. 6. 2 says, ÎºÎ»Î±Ï€ÎµÎ¹Ïƒá¿¶Î½ á¼Î¾ Î•á½Î²Î¿á½·Î±Ï‚ á½‘Ï€á½¸ Î‘á½Ï„Î¿Î»á½»ÎºÎ¿Ï… Î²Î¿á¿¶Î½. For Î½Î¿Î¼á½±Î´Î±Ï‚, â€˜wandering,â€™ cp. O.T. 1350 n.

Sic. 4. 31 Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼€Î½Î±Î²Î¹Î²á½±ÏƒÎ±Ï‚ á½ á¼©ÏÎ±ÎºÎ»á¿†Ï‚ á¼Ï€á½· Ï„Î¹Î½Î± Ï€á½»ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ á½‘ÏˆÎ·Î»á½¸Î½ á¼Îºá½³Î»ÎµÏ…ÏƒÎµÎ½ á¼€Ï†Î¿Ïá¾¶Î½. The word Ï€á½»ÏÎ³Î¿Ï‚ oft.=a city-wall with its towers ( O. T.56 n.). Thus it would satisfy all these statements to suppose that Iphitus was thrown from some high part of the walls which encompassed Tiryns Ï„ÎµÎ¹Ï‡Î¹á½¹ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ±. And by Ï€Ï…ÏÎ³á½½Î´Î·Ï‚ Ï€Î»á½±Î¾ Sophocles may well have meant â€˜the summit of a tower-like building.â€™ Modern critics have usually held that he meant â€˜the top of a towering rock or cliffâ€™: and so the schol. here explains, á½‘ÏˆÎ·Î»Î¿á¿¦ á½„ÏÎ¿Ï…Ï‚. We need not press the argument that it is not well-suited to the locality. But it may be doubted whether a Greek poet would have compared a rock or cliff to a Ï€á½»ÏÎ³Î¿Ï‚ merely because it was high and steep. On the other hand, where Ï€Ï…ÏÎ³Î¿ÎµÎ¹Î´á½µÏ‚ occurs elsewhere, it refers to a building. Josephus Bell. The rejection of this verse (see cr. n.) would be deplorable. Deianeira rejoices, but <*>ls a certain sadness, and knows that she cannot help showing it; all the more she wishes to assure them how real her joy is.

á½…Î¼Ï‰Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼”Î½ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹ Ï„Î¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Îµá½– ÏƒÎºÎ¿Ï€Î¿Ï…Î¼á½³Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚ ğŸ—©

This shadow which flits across Deianeira's joy is the more dramatically impressive for the spectators, because it arises so naturally out of her tender sympathy for the captives. It is a touch worthy of the greatest master.

Ï‡Ï‰Ïá½µÏƒÎ±Î½Ï„Î±. The notion of hostile advance was associated with this verb in such phrases as á½Î¼á½¹ÏƒÎµ Ï‡Ï‰ÏÎµá¿–Î½. (1) The sense of Ï‡Ï‰ÏÎµá¿–Î½ Îµá¼´Ï‚ Ï„Î¹Î½Î± is usu. friendly in prose, as Thuc.5. 40; more rarely hostile, as id. 4. 95, and Soph. Î¼Î·Î´), Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹ Î´Ïá½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚, sc. Î´Ïá½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î±Ï‚: cp. El.1434Î½á¿¦Î½, Ï„á½° Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ Îµá½– Î¸á½³Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹, Ï„á½±Î´â€™ á½¡Ï‚ Ï€á½±Î»Î¹Î½ (sc. Îµá½– Î¸á¿†ÏƒÎ¸Îµ). Remark, as evidence that this suspected verse is genuine, the thoroughly idiomatic use of the fut. indic. with Îµá¼°, in connection with the prayer: â€˜if thou must do it, at least do it thus.â€™ So O. C.166Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Î½ Îµá¼´ Ï„Î¹Î½â€™ Î¿á¼´ÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚ | Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ á¼Î¼á½°Î½ Î»á½³ÏƒÏ‡Î±Î½, á¼€Î²á½±Ï„Ï‰Î½ á¼€Ï€Î¿Î²á½°Ï‚ | ...Ï†á½½Î½ÎµÎ¹.â€”á¼”Ï„Î¹ after Î¶á½½ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ is here almost pleonastic: cp. Ant.3(n.).

This verse is a development of Î¼á½µ Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ Îµá¼°Ïƒá½·Î´Î¿Î¹Î¼Î¹: â€˜may I never see it; nay, if it is ever to happen, may it not happen while I live.â€™ Her words unconsciously foreshadow the troubles which, after her death, were brought upon her children by Eurystheus ( Eur. Heracl.). Such an allusion is quite in the poet's manner (cp. n. on Soph. Ant.1080 ff.).

The objection to the verse as illogical assumes that the Î´á½³ in Î¼Î·Î´á½³ means â€˜or,â€™ and that, therefore, the wish â€˜not to seeâ€™ the woe is distinguished from a wish which it includes,â€”viz., that the woe may not come while she lives. The answer is simply that the Î´á½³ in Î¼Î·Î´á½³ means â€˜and.â€™

á½…Ïƒá¿³Ï€ÎµÏ is used as if Ï€Î»Îµá¿–ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½, instead of Î¼á½¹Î½Î·, followed: see O. C.743 n.

Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½ Î¿á¼¶Î´ÎµÎ½, like ÏƒÏ‰Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½ á¼Ï€á½·ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î±Î¹ ( O. T.589). IolÃ¨ (whose actual relation to Heracles appears from 1225 f.) is feeling not only bitter grief (326), but the new shame and embarrassment caused by the presence in which she stands. While the other captives are comparatively callous, she appears to Deianeira as one whose sense of the calamity is such as might be looked for in a maiden of noble birth and spirit. Ï†ÏÎ¿Î½Îµá¿–Î½ here denotes that fine intelligence which is formed by gentle breeding, and which contributes to delicate propriety of behaviour. So, in Ant.1250, it is conjectured of EurydicÃ¨ that, in her grief, she has sought privacy: Î³Î½á½½Î¼Î·Ï‚ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½Îº á¼„Ï€ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚, á½¥ÏƒÎ¸â€™ á¼Î¼Î±ÏÏ„á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½: and cp. the account of Panthea's á¼€ÏÎµÏ„á½´ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Îµá½ÏƒÏ‡Î·Î¼Î¿Ïƒá½»Î½Î· in Xen. Î•á½Ïá½»Ï„Î¿Ï… ÏƒÏ€Î¿Ïá½± Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼¦Î½; The only natural sense is, â€˜had Eurytus any issue?â€™ She had heard that he had sons (266). Further, in a mere surmise, such as this, the less direct inquiry seems the fitter.

ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½± Ï„Î¿Î¹ Î¼á½´ Îµá¼°Î´á½³Î½Î±Î¹ Ïƒá½³ Î³â€™ á¼¥Ï„Î¹Ï‚ Îµá¼¶. ğŸ—©
Line 321

ÎºÎ±á½¶ closely with Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½±, a very misfortune. Deianeira is deeply interested by the captive, and feels drawn towards her. She is anxious to know the stranger's story, in order to offer her personal sympathy. These words express the pain and regret which she would feel at not being able to do so. The subtle art of the poet's language here depends on the different shades of meaning possible for Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½±. When Deianeira at last learns all, that knowledge is to her a Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½± in the gravest sense: she knows that, in IolÃ¨, she has received a Ï€Î·Î¼Î¿Î½á½´Î½ á½‘Ï€á½¹ÏƒÏ„ÎµÎ³Î¿Î½ (376). But here she is courteously using Î¾Ï…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½± in the milder sense which it could also bear,â€”â€˜a matter of deep regret.â€™ Cp. Her.1. 216ÏƒÏ…Î¼Ï†Î¿Ïá½´Î½ Ï€Î¿Î¹Îµá½»Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î¹ á½…Ï„Î¹ Î¿á½Îº á¼µÎºÎµÏ„Î¿ á¼Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Ï„Ï…Î¸á¿†Î½Î±Î¹.

Î›á½·. Î¿á½” Ï„á¼„ÏÎ± Ï„á¿· Î³Îµ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½ Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼Î¾ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Ï… ğŸ—©
Line 322

Î¿á½” Ï„á¼„ÏÎ± Îº.Ï„.Î».: lit., â€˜It will be in a manner very unlike the past that she will utter a wordâ€™: i.e., if she does speak, it will be very unlike her conduct hitherto. Î¿á½Î´á½²Î½ á¼Î¾ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Ï… must be taken together: for Ï„á¿· Î³Îµ Ï€Ïá½¹ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½ Ï‡Ïá½¹Î½á¿³ depending on á¼Î¾ á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Ï…, cp. Eur. Hipp.302á¼´ÏƒÎ¿Î½ Î´â€™ á¼„Ï€ÎµÏƒÎ¼ÎµÎ½ Ï„á¿· Ï€Ïá½·Î½. Î´Î¹á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹ is a certain correction of Î´Î¹Î¿á½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹: Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½ here is fig., â€˜speech,â€™ precisely as in fr. 844. 3 Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½´Î½ Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼ÎºÏ‡á½³Î±Ï‚ Î¼á½±Ï„Î·Î½, and Soph. El.596á¼£ Ï€á¾¶ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼µÎ·Ï‚ Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½: for á¼±á½³Î½Î±Î¹ Î³Î»á¿¶ÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½ could not mean, â€˜to unlooseâ€™ the tongue: it means â€˜to send forthâ€™ an utterance, being a poetical equiv. for á¼±á½³Î½Î±Î¹ Ï†Ï‰Î½á½µÎ½: cp. C.963ï¼ˆÏ†á½¹Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Î¼Î¿Î¹...) Ï„Î¿á¿¦ ÏƒÎ¿á¿¦ Î´Î¹á¿†ÎºÎ±Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚. The attempted interpretations of Î´Î¹Î¿á½·ÏƒÎµÎ¹, and some other conjectures, will be found in the Appendix.

Î¿á½Î´Î±Î¼á½°, adv.: O. C.1104 n.

Î´Î¹á½µÎ½ÎµÎ¼Î¿Î½ simply = á¼ Î½ÎµÎ¼á½¹ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ±Î½: so Oechalia is called á½‘Ïˆá½·Ï€Ï…ÏÎ³Î¿Ï‚ (354) and Î±á¼°Ï€ÎµÎ¹Î½á½µ (858). The word does not occur elsewhere in classical Greek, but Hermann quotes it from Philo Byzant. De septem mirabilibus 1, where it means â€˜fanned by breezes.â€™ Hermann prefers the first of the two explanations (á¼”ÏÎ·Î¼Î¿Î½, á½‘ÏˆÎ·Î»á½µÎ½) given by the schol.: thinking that the epithet describes the ruins of Oechalia as patulum ventis iter praebentes. This seems very far-fetched; the more so, as the noun is Ï€á½±Ï„ÏÎ±Î½.

á¼¡ â€¦ Ï„á½Ï‡Î·, not the doom of captivity, but rather her present condition of mute and inconsolable grief.

Î±á½Ï„á¿‡ Î³) is emphatic; sad for her, but to be condoned by us: Î³) is therefore in place.

331 Among the attempts to amend Î»á½»Ï€Î·Î½...Î»á½»Ï€Î·Î½ (cr. n.), the two best, I think, are, (1) á¼„Î»Î»Î·Î½ â€¦ Î»á½»Ï€Î·Î½, Triclinius: and (2) Î»á½»Ï€Î·Î½ â€¦ Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¿†Î½, F. W. Schmidt. But it is also conceivable that the error should have arisen through the transcriber glancing forward. And, in close connection with Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ ÎºÎ±ÎºÎ¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î¿á½–ÏƒÎ¹Î½, á¼„Î»Î»Î·Î½ seems the fittest word. Î´Î¹Ï€Î»á¿†Î½ would be less clear (meaning the former ÎºÎ±Îºá½± plus a new Î»á½»Ï€Î·): it would also be too emphatic for this context.

á¼€Î¼Î¼Îµá½·Î½Î±Ï‚): Sophocles has the form á¼€Î¼Î¼á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ in four lyric passages (527, 648, El.1389 El., 1397); but there is no other instance of it in tragic iambics. á¼ŒÎ³. 340 ÏƒÏ„Î±Î¸Îµá¿–Ïƒâ€™ á¼„ÎºÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¿Î½Â· ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î³á½°Ï Î¿á½Î´á½² Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï€á½±ÏÎ¿Ï‚ ğŸ—©

á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Ï…Ï‚, Lichas and the captives: who are moving away into the house, but have not yet disappeared. Their movement, which would begin at v. 335, ends only at 345. á½ á¿¥Î¹Ï€Ï„á½¸Ï‚ â€¦ Î¼á½¹ÏÎ¿Ï‚: cp. Ant.36Ï†á½¹Î½Î¿Î½... Î´Î·Î¼á½¹Î»ÎµÏ…ÏƒÏ„Î¿Î½. A sarcastic allusion to the vivid detail with which Lichas had told the story (270 ff.).

Heracles had really killed Iphitus. The denial here refers only to the place which the murder held in the story told by Lichas. Heracles was instigated, not by the Lydian servitude which punished his crime, or by those affronts (262 ff.) which Lichas represented as having moved him to the crime, but, in reality, by the refusal of Eurytus to give him IolÃ¨.
