Line 964

Î¾á½³Î½á¿³Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». It should be observed how the poet has marked successive stages in the approach of the litter. When it first comes into view, the Chorus note the foreign aspect of the bearers. á¼€Î¿Î¹Î´á½¹Ï‚=á¼Ï€á¿³Î´á½¹Ï‚, one who uses á¼Ï€á¿³Î´Î±á½·, incantations, in healing: see on O. C.1194.

Ï„á½·Ï‚ á½ Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ¿Ï„á½³Ï‡Î½Î·Ï‚, sc. á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·Î½. (There is no art. before á¼€Î¿Î¹Î´á½¹Ï‚, because the insertion of á½ƒÏ‚ was an afterthought.) Line 1003

Î¸Î±á¿¦Î¼â€™ á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½¹ÏÏÏ‰Î¸ÎµÎ½ á¼°Î´Î¿á½·Î¼Î·Î½: â€˜I should look upon him, from afar, as a wonder,â€™â€”i.e., â€˜I should marvel as soon as he came within my ken.â€™ He means that he might scan the horizon long enough, in the vain hope of such a prodigy appearing.â€”Others join Ï€á½¹ÏÏÏ‰Î¸ÎµÎ½ with Î¸<*>Î¼Î±: â€˜I should behold him as a wonder from some distant regionâ€™: i.e., the place which contains him must be distant indeed. Hermann further supposed a question: â€˜am I likely to see such a wonder coming from afar?â€™â€”The phrase Ï„Î·Î»á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ Îµá¼°ÏƒÎ¿Ïá¿¶Î½ in Ph.454 is not similar: see n. there.

á¼©Ï. á¼’ á¼”, ğŸ—©
Line 10041004-1043

This passage consists of lyrics delivered by actors (á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á¿†Ï‚). As the Chorus takes no part in it, it is not technically a ÎºÎ¿Î¼Î¼á½¹Ï‚, which is a Î¸Ïá¿†Î½Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½á½¸Ï‚ Ï‡Î¿ÏÎ¿á¿¦ ÎºÎ±á½¶ á¼€Ï€á½¸ ÏƒÎºÎ·Î½á¿†Ï‚.

The lyric structure is complex, but not obscure. The passage falls into two main parts, separated by the five hexameters in 1018â€”1022 (á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿– Ï„Î¿á¿¦Î´â€™ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚...Î½á½³Î¼ÎµÎ¹ Î–Îµá½»Ï‚). I. The first part consists of 1004â€”1017, in which the first three verses correspond metrically with the last three. II. The second part consists of 1023â€”1043. (It is equal in length with the first part, though the traditional numbering makes it appear longer.) Here, the first four verses correspond with the last four. Then the central portion of part I. corresponds with the central portion of part II. Thus: (1) 1st strophe, 1004â€”1006,=1st antistr., 1015â€”1017. (2) 2nd str., 1007â€”1009,=2nd antistr., 1027â€”1030. (3) 3rd str., 1023â€”1026, =3rd antistr., 1040â€”1043. The dactyls in 1010â€”1014, and 1031â€”1040, could also be regarded as forming a fourth strophe and antistrophe.â€”For the metres see Metrical Analysis.

Î Î±Î»Î»á½±Ï‚. Athena was always a guardian goddess to her half-brother, Heracles; of whom she says in Il.8. 363 ff., Ï„ÎµÎ¹Ïá½¹Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½ Ïƒá½½ÎµÏƒÎºÎ¿Î½ á½‘Ï€â€™ Î•á½ÏÏ…ÏƒÎ¸á¿†Î¿Ï‚ á¼€á½³Î¸Î»Ï‰Î½Â· | á¼¦ Ï„Î¿Î¹ á½ Î¼á½²Î½ ÎºÎ»Î±á½·ÎµÏƒÎºÎµ Ï€Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½ÏÎ±Î½á½¹Î½, Î±á½Ï„á½°Ï á¼Î¼á½² Î–Îµá½ºÏ‚ | Ï„á¿· á¼Ï€Î±Î»ÎµÎ¾á½µÏƒÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½ á¼€Ï€â€™ Î¿á½ÏÎ±Î½á½¹Î¸ÎµÎ½ Ï€ÏÎ¿á¿“Î±Î»Î»ÎµÎ½. She was constantly represented in Greek art as present with Heracles during his labours, or as honouring and comforting him in seasons of repose. Sometimes she gives him a flower or a wreath; sometimes a refreshing draught. And, after the close of his mortal toils, it is Athena NikÃ¨ who escorts him to Olympus. (Cp. n. on Ph.728.) The art-literature of the subject will be found in Roscher, Lex., p. 2215. Attic black-figure vases often illustrate this relationship,â€”one which was the more welcome to Athenians because Heracles was essentially a Dorian hero.

á¼©Ï. á½¦ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î´á½´ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î¸ÎµÏÎ¼á½° ÎºÎ¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ ÎºÎ±Îºá½° ğŸ—©
Line 1046

á½¦ Ï€Î¿Î»Î»á½° Î´á½´ Îº.Ï„.Î». This speech, down to v. 1102, is translated by Cicero in Tusc.2. 8, where the fact that the poets recognise pain as an evil is illustrated by the laments of Philoctetes, Heracles and Prometheus.

Cicero's version is essentially that of an orator; the true test for it would be declamation. But even a reader can feel its sonorous vigour, and its Roman gravity; Cicero succeeds as Lord Derby succeeded in much of the Iliad. The rendering of the Greek is very free, sometimes inadequate, but always manly, and highly terse; indeed, the 57 lines of the original become 45; in one place, eleven verses (1079â€”1089) are reduced to four (vv. 30â€”33).

Î¸ÎµÏÎ¼á½°: Î¸ÎµÏÎ¼á½¹Ï‚ was said (1) of a hot or rash temperament ( Ant.88): (2) of a rash deed, as in Plut 415 á½¦ Î¸ÎµÏÎ¼á½¸Î½ á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ Îºá¼€Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¹Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï€Î±Ïá½±Î½Î¿Î¼Î¿Î½ | Ï„Î¿Î»Î¼á¿¶Î½Ï„Îµ Î´Ïá¾¶Î½. Here Î¸ÎµÏÎ¼á½° is not â€˜rash,â€™ but expresses intense conflict with deadly peril; as we speak of â€˜a hot fight.â€™

ÎºÎ¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ ÎºÎ±Îºá½° fitly follows Î¸ÎµÏÎ¼á½±, the word which recalls the moment of dire stress. His trials had been fiery, and grievous, not in report or name alone. No Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï‚ could express to others what the á¼”ÏÎ³Î± had been to the doer. In El.761 ff. a similar antithesis is implied: Ï„Î¿Î¹Î±á¿¦Ï„á½± ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„â€™ á¼ÏƒÏ„á½·Î½, á½¡Ï‚ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Î½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ | á¼€Î»Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½á½±, Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Î´â€™ á¼°Î´Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ¹Î½, Î¿á¼µÏ€ÎµÏ Îµá¼´Î´Î¿Î¼ÎµÎ½, | Î¼á½³Î³Î¹ÏƒÏ„Î± Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½ á½§Î½ á½„Ï€Ï‰Ï€â€™ á¼Î³á½¼ ÎºÎ±Îºá¿¶Î½: grievous enough to hear; but far worse to see. For Î¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³, cp. Ai.813ÎºÎ¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Î´Îµá½·Î¾Ï‰ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½: El.1453Îºá¼€Ï€á½³Î´ÎµÎ¹Î¾ÎµÎ½ Î¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ Î¼á½¹Î½Î¿Î½. Thuc.6. 18á¼€Î¼á½»Î½ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á¼”ÏÎ³á¿³ Î¼á¾¶Î»Î»Î¿Î½.

The MS. reading, ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ ÎºÎ±Îºá½°, is certainly wrong, for two reasons. (1) When the required sense is, â€˜grievous to tell,â€™ ÎºÎ±Îºá½± becomes, for Greek poetical idiom, too weak; we need such a word as Î´ÎµÎ¹Î½á½± or á¼€Î»Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½á½±. This objection does not apply to a phrase of ironical form, such as Î¿á½ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ ÎºÎ±Îºá½±. (2) Idiom would require ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½³Î³ÎµÎ¹Î½ rather than ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³. Cicero, no doubt, read ÎºÎ±á½¶ Î»á½¹Î³á¿³ (â€˜O multa dictu gravia, perpessu asperaâ€™); but that proves nothing. In Ant.4Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼„Ï„Î·Ï‚ á¼„Ï„ÎµÏ was the only reading known to Didymus (c. 30 B.C.).

Line 1047

Ï‡ÎµÏÏƒá½¶ refers to deeds of prowess: Î½á½½Ï„Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ to feats of sheer strength, as when he took the place of Atlas, or carried the Erymanthian boar to Mycenae.â€”Cicero's version, Quae corpore exanclavi atque animo pertuli, has caused the inference that his text contained an equivalent for animo. Wecklein suggests that he read ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ½Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ (cp. 1090), but misunderstood it. Perhaps, however, Cicero felt his rhetorical antithesis to be warranted by the idea of mental anguish implied in Î¼Î¿Ï‡Î¸á½µÏƒÎ±Ï‚.

ÎºÎ¿á½”Ï€Ï‰ Ï„Î¿Î¹Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼„ÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼¡ Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ ğŸ—©

ÎºÎ¿á½”Ï€Ï‰: ÎºÎ±á½· here=â€˜and neverthelessâ€™; cp. Ant.332 n.

á¼„ÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï„Î¹Ï‚ á¼¡ Î”Î¹á½¸Ï‚ (for the place of the art., cp. 732), since the á¼€ÏÎ³Î±Î»á½³Î¿Ï‚ Ï‡á½¹Î»Î¿Ï‚ á¼­ÏÎ·Ï‚ ( Il.18. 119) was the prime source of all his troubles. Hera caused Eurystheus to be born at Argos a little before the birth of Heracles at Thebes ( Il.19. 114 ff.), and afterwards gave the hero into his power. But she also persecuted Heracles directly, as when she sent the serpents to his cradle ( Pind. N.1. 40), or drove him by storms to Cos ( Il.14. 253 ff.).

á¿¥Î¿Ï†Îµá¿–, â€˜drains,â€™ â€˜emptiesâ€™ (of air): his breath is arrested by the spasms: cp. 778 ÏƒÏ€Î±ÏÎ±Î³Î¼á½¸Ï‚...Ï€Î»ÎµÏ…Î¼á½¹Î½Ï‰Î½ á¼€Î½Î¸á½µÏˆÎ±Ï„Î¿. á¼€Ï†Ïá½±ÏƒÏ„á¿³, â€˜indescribable,â€™ unutterably dreadful; not, â€˜inexplicable,â€™ i.e., of unknown origin.

Ï‡ÎµÎ¹ÏÏ‰Î¸Îµá½¶Ï‚: cp. 279 n.

ÎºÎ¿á½ Ï„Î±á¿¦Ï„Î± Î»á½¹Î³Ï‡Î· Ï€ÎµÎ´Î¹á½±Ï‚, Î¿á½”Î¸â€™ á½ Î³Î·Î³ÎµÎ½á½´Ï‚ ğŸ—©
Line 1058

ÎºÎ¿á½ â€¦ Î¿á½”Î¸). It is unnecessary to change Î¿á½”Î¸) to Î¿á½Î´). The sequence Î¿á½...Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ is foreign to Attic prose; and an Attic poet would presumably have avoided it where Î¿á½ was followed by only one negative clause: e.g., in O. C.702Î¿á½ Î½ÎµÎ±Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³á½µÏá¾³, etc., Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ is improbable. In Theognis 125 Î¿á½ Î³á½°Ï á¼‚Î½ Îµá¼°Î´Îµá½·Î·Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î´Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î½á½¹Î¿Î½ Î¿á½Î´á½² Î³Ï…Î½Î±Î¹Îºá½¹Ï‚, where the MSS. have Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ, Î¿á½Î´á½² stands in Aristotle's quotation of the verse (Eth. Eud. 7. 2). But when, as here, several clauses with Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ follow Î¿á½, an Attic poet might imitate the frequent Homeric usage: e.g., Od.4. 566Î¿á½ Î½Î¹Ï†ÎµÏ„á½¸Ï‚ Î¿á½”Ï„â€™ á¼‚Ï Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î¼á½¼Î½ Ï€Î¿Î»á½ºÏ‚ Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ Ï€Î¿Ï„â€™ á½„Î¼Î²ÏÎ¿Ï‚. So ib. 9. 136 f. Î¿á½ is followed by two clauses with Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ, and in Il.6. 450 f. by three.

Î»á½¹Î³Ï‡Î· Ï€ÎµÎ´Î¹á½±Ï‚, the spear of the warrior on a battle-field; as when Heracles fought with Laomedon of Troy, with the Amazons, or with Augeas king of Elis ( Apollod.2. 7. 2).

ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„á½¸Ï‚ Î“Î¹Î³á½±Î½Ï„Ï‰Î½: after sacking Troy, and ravaging Cos, Heracles went to Phlegra (sometimes identified with PallenÃ¨, the westernmost headland of the Chalcidic peninsula), and helped the gods to vanquish their Earth-born foes. In Pind. N.1. 67Teiresias predicts what Heracles shall achieve, á½…Ï„Î±Î½ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á½¶ á¼Î½ Ï€ÎµÎ´á½·á¿³ Î¦Î»á½³Î³ÏÎ±Ï‚ Î“Î¹Î³á½±Î½Ï„ÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î¼á½±Ï‡Î±Î½ | á¼€Î½Ï„Î¹á½±Î¶Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹Î½. In the Gigantomachia on the pediment of the Megarian Treasury at Olympia, Heracles fought at the right hand of Zeus (cp. Ausgrabungen, vol. IV. pl. 20 b). Early Attic vase-paintings of this subject associate him with Zeus and Athena (Roscher, Lex., p. 2211).

Î¸á½µÏÎµÎ¹Î¿Ï‚ Î²á½·Î± seems to be a general phrase, including both the Centaurs (Î¸Î·Ïá¿¶Î½, 1096) and the wild beasts (1092 ff.). Cicero understood it of the former only, non biformato impetu | Centaurus.

Cicero represents this passage by a single verse, Iam cernam, mene an illam potiorem putes. Hence Nauck rejects v. 1069. But the inference is most unsafe, as another instance will show. The passage beginning with á¼°Î´Î¿á½» (1079) and ending with á¼Î¾á½½ÏÎ¼Î·ÎºÎµÎ½ (1089) shrinks, in Cicero's version, to three lines and a half, viz., Videte cuncti: tuque, caelestum sator, | Iace, obsecro, in me vim coruscam fulminis! | Nunc, nunc dolorum anxiferi torquent vertices: | Nunc serpit ardor. Thus Cicero wholly ignores vv. 1085 ff.: he ignores vv. 1080â€”1084 also, except in so far as their general sense is blended with his version of 1088 f., Î´Î±á½·Î½Ï…Ï„Î±Î¹...á¼Î¾á½½ÏÎ¼Î·ÎºÎµÎ½. Yet the Greek text there is clearly sound.

1081 It is best to retain Î±á¼°Î±á¿–, á½¦ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Ï‚, Î±á¼°Î±á¿–, L's reading. Hermann and others, taking Î±á¼°Î±á¿– á½¦ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Ï‚ as a dochmiac, read á¼á½³ or á¼’ á¼” instead of the second Î±á¼°Î±á¿–, placing it in a line by itself. Nauck requires bacchii, and suggests á¼°á½½ Î¼Î¿Î¹, Ï„á½±Î»Î±Ï‚, Ï†Îµá¿¦. Wilam. (Hermes XVIII. 246) saysâ€”(1) Î±á¼°Î±á¿–, á½¦ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Ï‚, dochmius: (2) Î±á¼°Î±á¿–, interjection: (3) á½¦Î½Î±Î¾ ...Ï€Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¿Î½, â€˜acatalectic anapaestic trimeter.â€™ A brief interjection of this kind could take almost any metrical form; and, in the absence of a lyric context, the metre here cannot be defined with certainty. ÎÎµÎ¼á½³Î±Ï‚, a valley in Argolis, about three miles S.W. of Cleonae, four and a half S. E. of Phlius, and eleven N. of Argos. Î²á½·á¾³ ÎºÎ±Ï„ÎµÎ¹ÏÎ³á½±ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¸Îµ: Heracles throttled the lion, which was invulnerable: Eur. H. F.153á½ƒÎ½ á¼Î½ Î²Ïá½¹Ï‡Î¿Î¹Ï‚ á¼‘Î»á½¼Î½ | Î²ÏÎ±Ï‡á½·Î¿Î½á½¹Ï‚ Ï†Î·Ïƒâ€™ á¼€Î³Ï‡á½¹Î½Î±Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á¼Î¾ÎµÎ»Îµá¿–Î½. This was the first of his labours; and thus he won the lion-skin ( Pind. I.5. 47).

1095 f. The next two exploits are also linked. Sentby Eurystheus in quest of the Îºá½±Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï‚ (Î¸á¿†ÏÎ± 1097) that haunted Mount Erymanthus in north Arcadia, Heracles passed over PholoÃ¨, a wild upland district on the borders of Elis. Here he was entertained by the Centaur Pholos, and routed the other Centaurs who flocked to demand a share of his host's wine.

á¼Î¹Î´Î¿Ï… Ï„Ïá½·ÎºÏÎ±Î½Î¿Î½ ÏƒÎºá½»Î»Î±Îº): a three-headed Cerberus seems to have been the usual type in early Ionian art; while on Attic black-figure vases of the middle and later style he is two-headed: see Roscher, Lex.p. 2205. Hesiod, the first poet who names Cerberus ( Th.311), gives him fifty heads.

á¼˜Ï‡á½·Î´Î½Î·Ï‚ Î¸Ïá½³Î¼Î¼Î±, as in Hes. Th.310: but in Soph. O. C.1574 he is the offspring of Tartarus and Earth. In Il.8. 366 ff. Athena saves Heracles when Eurystheus sends him á¼Î¾ á¼Ïá½³Î²ÎµÏ…Ï‚ á¼„Î¾Î¿Î½Ï„Î± Îºá½»Î½Î± ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³ÎµÏÎ¿á¿¦ á¼ˆá¿“Î´Î±Î¿: cp. Od.11. 623.â€”Pluto said that Heracles might take Cerberus, if he could do so without using any weapon. The hero succeeded, and having shown his living prize to the terrified Eurystheus, restored it to the nether world. ( Apollod.2. 5. 12Â§ 8.)

Ï‡ÏÏ…Ïƒá½³Ï‰Î½: in tragic dialogue Ï‡Ïá½»ÏƒÎµÎ¿Ï‚ usu. suffers synizesis, but there are several exceptions, such as fr. 313: fr. 439: Eur. Ion1175.

The golden apples, brought from the garden of the gods, originally meant the winning of immortality. Hence this á¼†Î¸Î»Î¿Ï‚ properly comes after the Cerberus, though the latter is sometimes made the last ( Eur. H. F.427).

Î´Ïá½±ÎºÎ¿Î½Ï„Î± Î¼á½µÎ»Ï‰Î½ Ï†á½»Î»Î±Îº). The garden was in the far west, where Atlas supports the sky, beyond the stream of the Oceanus ( Hes. Th.215). When Zeus espoused Hera there, a wondrous apple-tree (Î¼Î·Î»á½³Î±) sprang up. This tree was committed to the care of maidens called Hesperides, daughters of Night ( Hes. Th.211), sweet singers; and it was guarded by a terrible dragon, coiled round the stem ( Eur. H. F.397, Paus.6. 19. 8). Heracles slew this dragon with poisoned arrows (Apoll. Rh. 4.1396 ff., where the monster is named Î›á½±Î´Ï‰Î½).

Î³á½°Ï justifies Ï‡ÏÎ·ÏƒÏ„á½° Î¼Ï‰Î¼á½³Î½Î·. â€”ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î·Î¼Î± occurs only here. Its formation from ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³â€Ï‰ is anomalous, since the word ought to be ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î¼Î±: but the same may be said of ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î·Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½ (instead of ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎºÏ„ÏÎ¿Î½): and Î¸á½³Î»Î³Î·Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½ was in use along with Î¸á½³Î»ÎºÏ„ÏÎ¿Î½. As to sense, ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î·Î¸ÏÎ¿Î½, like Ï†á½·Î»Ï„ÏÎ¿Î½, is â€˜an instrument for producing loveâ€™; while ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î·Î¼Î±, like Ï†á½·Î»Î·Î¼Î±, ought to denote an effect. But here, again, we must allow for the freedom of poetical diction. The analogy of Îºá½µÎ»Î·Î¼Î±, â€˜a spellâ€™ ( Eur. For these reasons I refrain from changing ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î·Î¼Î±, with Nauck, to ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î·Î¸ÏÎ±.

Ïƒá½³Î¸ÎµÎ½, objective gen. with ÏƒÏ„á½³ÏÎ³Î·Î¼Î±.

á¼©Ï. á¼°Î¿á½º á¼°Î¿á½º Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚, Î¿á¼´Ï‡Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Ï‚Â· ğŸ—©
Line 1143

á¼°Î¿á½º á¼°Î¿á½º, as in O. T.1071(Iocasta) O. T., 1182(Oedipus).

Î´á½»ÏƒÏ„Î·Î½Î¿Ï‚: for the nom., cp. 986.

Î¿á¼´Ï‡Î¿Î¼Î±Î¹. From the beginning of his torments, Heracles has felt that they could end only in death (cp. 802: 1001: 1111). Why, then, should he now speak as if he realised his state for the first time? The answer seems to be that, though the ultimate prospect is unchanged, his doom acquires a new terror in the light of its supernatural source. Hitherto he has believed himself the victim of human malice: it might leave no hope, but still it fixed no term. Now he knows that he is in the grip of á¼€Î½á½±Î³ÎºÎ·: his moments are numbered. Henceforth he thinks only of the end.

The oracles can be only the two which are told to Hyllus (1159â€”1171). If there had been others, they also must have been confided to him, as representing the absent kinsfolk. Heracles wishes to gather his family around him at a solemn farewell,â€”to convince them, by the Î¸á½³ÏƒÏ†Î±Ï„Î±, that he is in the hand of Zeus,â€”and, with that sanction, to lay his last commands upon them all.

Î¿á½”Ï„Îµ is followed by Î´á½² (1153), as in Aesch. Suppl.223 ff., Xen. An.6. 3. 16(=6. 1. 16 of some edd.), Plat. Rep. 389A, etc. Cp. 143 n.

á¼Ï€Î±ÎºÏ„á½·á¾³ Î¤á½·ÏÏ…Î½Î¸Î¹: see on 270.

ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²á½³Î²Î·ÎºÎµÎ½, impers., it has come to pass: the subject to á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ (Î±á½Ï„á½µÎ½) can easily be supplied, and the whole phrase =Ï„Ï…Î³Ï‡á½±Î½ÎµÎ¹ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Î½ á¼”Ï‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ±. â€” For á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ, cp. Arist. Pol.2. 2. 5ÎºÎ±á½¶ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ Î´á½´ Ï„á½¸Î½ Ï„Ïá½¹Ï€Î¿Î½ Ï„Î¿á¿¦Ï„Î¿Î½ á½¥ÏƒÏ„Îµ Ï€á½±Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ á¼„ÏÏ‡ÎµÎ¹Î½.â€” Not, â€˜she has come to terms (with Eurystheus), so that she should dwell,â€™ etc.

Sophocles glances here at parts of the story which do not come within the scope of the play. Alcmena, daughter of Electryon king of Mycenae, had been betrothed to her first cousin, Amphitryon, son of Alcaeus king of Tiryns. Amphitryon accidentally killed his uncle, Electryon, and then fled from Tiryns to Thebes with his betrothed. At Thebes Alcmena bore Heracles to Zeus. Heracles afterwards went to Argolis and served Eurystheus,â€”with the hope that his toils would purchase a return to Tiryns for the exiled Amphitryon and Alcmena ( Eur. H. F.19). When these toils were over, Heracles dwelt in freedom at Tiryns with his family, including Alcmena,â€”Amphitryon being dead ( Diod.4. 33). He afterwards slew Iphitus, and then sought a refuge for his household at Trachis (39). But, in the course of the fifteen months since he departed for Lydia, Alcmena had returned to Tiryns, (Eurystheus having no cause to fear the aged widow,)â€”and had taken some of her grandchildren with her, in order to lighten the burden on the hospitality of CeÃ¿x.â€” Î¾Ï…Î»Î»Î±Î²Î¿á¿¦Ï‚), here simply=Î»Î±Î²Î¿á¿¦ÏƒÎ± Î¼ÎµÎ¸â€™ á¼‘Î±Ï…Ï„á¿†Ï‚: cp. O. T.971 n.

Î¤á½·ÏÏ…Î½Î¸Î¹ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²á½³Î²Î·ÎºÎµÎ½ á½¥ÏƒÏ„â€™ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼•Î´ÏÎ±Î½.
Ï€Î±á½·Î´Ï‰Î½ Î´á½² Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î¼á½²Î½ Î¾Ï…Î»Î»Î±Î²Î¿á¿¦Ïƒâ€™ Î±á½Ï„á½´ Ï„Ïá½³Ï†ÎµÎ¹,
Ï„Î¿á½ºÏ‚ Î´â€™ á¼‚Î½ Ï„á½¸ Î˜á½µÎ²Î·Ï‚ á¼„ÏƒÏ„Ï… Î½Î±á½·Î¿Î½Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î¼á½±Î¸Î¿Î¹Ï‚Â· ğŸ—©

Ï„á½¸ Î˜á½µÎ²Î·Ï‚ á¼„ÏƒÏ„Ï…. Thebes, the birthplace of Heracles (116), and his early home (510), was a place where some of his children might well find friends. Sophocles has perhaps taken a hint here from his elder contemporary, the logographer Pherecydes, who related that, after the death of Eurystheus, Thebes became the home of the Heracleidae; fr. 39 (MÃ¼ller Frag. Ï€Ïá½¹Ï†Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î½ á¼Îº Ï€Î±Ï„Ïá½¸Ï‚: this oracle, given by Zeus at an unspecified time, and place, is not mentioned elsewhere in the play. Nor is it noticed by any other writer. Sophocles may, however, have found it in some earlier treatment of the fable.

á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚: for the ellipse of the antecedent (á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Ï…), cp. Ai.1050Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„â€™ á¼Î¼Î¿á½·, Î´Î¿ÎºÎ¿á¿¦Î½Ï„Î± Î´â€™ á½ƒÏ‚ ÎºÏÎ±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹ ÏƒÏ„ÏÎ±Ï„Î¿á¿¦. Eur. Ion560á¼¦ Î¸á½·Î³Ï‰ Î´á¿†Î¸â€™ Î¿á¼µ Î¼â€™ á¼”Ï†Ï…ÏƒÎ±Î½;â€”á¼Î¹Î´Î¿Ï… â€¦ Î¿á¼°Îºá½µÏ„Ï‰Ï: 282.

á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ â€¦ Ï€á½³Î»Î¿Î¹: if we suppose that Nessus was alive when Zeus spoke, then this is oblique for á½…ÏƒÏ„Î¹Ï‚ á¼‚Î½ Ï€á½³Î»á¿ƒ, as O. á½…Î´â€™ Î¿á½–Î½ á½ Î¸á½´Ï Îšá½³Î½Ï„Î±Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚, á½¡Ï‚ Ï„á½¸ Î¸Îµá¿–Î¿Î½ á¼¦Î½ ğŸ—©
Line 1162

Î¸á½´Ï (556) is in appos. with Îšá½³Î½Ï„Î±Ï…ÏÎ¿Ï‚.

Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„á½± Î¼â€™ á¼”ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ¹Î½ÎµÎ½ Î¸Î±Î½á½½Î½: as the dead Hector brought death on Ajax ( Ai.1027). For other examples of this favourite antithesis, cp. O. T.1453 n.: Ant.871 n.: Ai.901: El.808.

Ï€Ïá½¹Ï†Î±Î½Ï„Î¿Î½, Î¿á½•Ï„Ï‰ Î¶á¿¶Î½Ï„á½± Î¼â€™ á¼”ÎºÏ„ÎµÎ¹Î½ÎµÎ½ Î¸Î±Î½á½½Î½.
Ï†Î±Î½á¿¶ Î´â€™ á¼Î³á½¼ Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²Î±á½·Î½Î¿Î½Ï„â€™ á¼´ÏƒÎ± ğŸ—©
Line 1164

Ï„Î¿á½»Ï„Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹ Îº.Ï„.Î». The Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá¿–Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹Î½á½° denote the oracle given at Dodona twelve years before this time, saying that at the end of the twelfth year Heracles should have rest. This is the oracle to which allusion was made in 44, 164 ff., 824 ff. The other and earlier oracle (1159 ff.) had predicted the agency: this Dodonaean oracle, â€˜recentâ€™ in a relative sense, predicted the time. The two oracles â€˜agree,â€™ because each verifies the other. The thing has come to pass by the right agency at the right time.

ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²Î±á½·Î½Î¿Î½Ï„â€™ á¼´ÏƒÎ±, â€˜coming out in agreement with them,â€™â€”yielding the same result,â€”viz., that this is the predicted end. For ÏƒÏ…Î¼Î²Î±á½·Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½, cp. 173 n. The idea is emphatically repeated in Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á½±Î»Î±Î¹ Î¾Ï…Î½á½µÎ³Î¿ÏÎ±, â€˜pleading on the side of the older oracle,â€™â€”upholding its truth. Cp. 814 Î¾Ï…Î½Î·Î³Î¿ÏÎµá¿–Ï‚.

1165 Î¼Î±Î½Ï„Îµá¿–Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹Î½á½±, Ï„Î¿á¿–Ï‚ Ï€á½±Î»Î±Î¹ Î¾Ï…Î½á½µÎ³Î¿ÏÎ±,
á¼ƒ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½€ÏÎµá½·Ï‰Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï‡Î±Î¼Î±Î¹ÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï„á¿¶Î½ á¼Î³á½¼ ğŸ—©
Line 1166

á¼ƒ Ï„á¿¶Î½ á½€ÏÎµá½·Ï‰Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». The Î£ÎµÎ»Î»á¿¶Î½ á¼„Î»ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚ is the sacred precinct at Dodona, including the temple of Zeus, with its temenos; its limits have been traced by Carapanos (Dodone, pp. 16â€” 23): see Appendix, note on this passage, Â§ 2.

The name Î£ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿á½·, or á¼™Î»Î»Î¿á½· (akin to á¼Î»Î»Î·Î½, á¼™Î»Î»á½±Ï‚), denoted a prehistoric tribe, dwelling at and around Dodona: see Appendix, Â§ 4. The priests of Zeus, furnished by this tribe, are said to have been called Ï„á½¹Î¼Î¿Ï…ÏÎ¿Î¹, from Mount TomÄros (Orphic Argon. 268 Î¤Î¿Î¼Î±Ïá½·Î±Ï‚ á¼”ÎºÎ»Ï…Îµ Ï†Î·Î³á½¹Ï‚), which towers above Dodona on W.S.W. In early times these priests were the direct interpreters of the oracle; hence the Î£ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿á½· are called á½‘Ï€Î¿Ï†á¿†Ï„Î±Î¹ in Il.16. 235.Afterwards, when the cult of DionÃ¨ was associated with that of Zeus, the office of interpretation was transferred to the priestesses called Peleiades (172: Strabo 7. 329). Here, as in 171 f., the poet says that the oak gave the oracle; but he does not here mention the expositors. He mentions the Î£ÎµÎ»Î»Î¿á½· only to define the á¼„Î»ÏƒÎ¿Ï‚.

á½€ÏÎµá½·Ï‰Î½ refers to the site of Dodona in a valley, more than 1600 feet above sea-level, surrounded by hills. See Appendix, Â§ 1.

Ï‡Î±Î¼Î±Î¹ÎºÎ¿Î¹Ï„á¿¶Î½, a trait of barbarism, surviving as a mark of sanctity. According to Philostratus (Imag. 2. 33), the Selli were â€˜men of a rude lifeâ€™ (Î±á½Ï„Î¿ÏƒÏ‡á½³Î´Î¹Î¿á½· Ï„Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚), who held that their austerities were pleasing to Zeus. Cp. Îµá¼°ÏƒÎµÎ³ÏÎ±Ïˆá½±Î¼Î·Î½, i.e., wrote for his own use in the Î´á½³Î»Ï„Î¿Ï‚ (157). Cp. á¼€Î»Î»), á½¦ Ï€á½±Ï„ÎµÏ: á¼€Î»Î»á½° here prefaces assent, as Ph.48 Ph., 524.

Ï„Î±ÏÎ²á¿¶ Î¼á½²Î½ Îº.Ï„.Î». The sense is: â€˜I am alarmed, indeed, at the issue to which you have brought me,â€”a choice between disobedience, and a blind promise; but I will obey.â€™ Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï… ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Ï„Î¿Î¹á½±Î½Î´Îµ, â€˜such a situation in our converseâ€™: á¼Ï€ÎµÎ»Î¸á½½Î½, â€˜having advanced,â€™ i.e., having been drawn on to it, by the progress of the dialogue. It may be noted that the sing. Î»á½¹Î³Î¿Ï… suits this sense of ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚: if the meaning had been, â€˜strife of wordsâ€™ (the ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ Î³Î»á½½ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ of O.T. 634), we should have expected rather the plur. Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½, as in Soph. Ph.1460Îµá¼°Ï‚ á¼”ÏÎ¹Î½ Î»á½¹Î³Ï‰Î½. For this general sense of ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚, status, cp. Phaedr. p. 253 D á½...á¼Î½ Ï„á¿‡ ÎºÎ±Î»Î»á½·Î¿Î½Î¹ ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹ á½¤Î½.

Throughout the dialogue (1114â€”1156), Hyllus has been gentle and respectful. If, then, ÏƒÏ„á½±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ means â€˜strife,â€™ á¼Ï€ÎµÎ»Î¸á½½Î½ must mean merely, â€˜having advanced up to it,â€™ i.e., â€˜come to the verge of it.â€™ But the clause with Î¼á½³Î½, opposed to Ï€Îµ<*>ÏƒÎ¿Î¼Î±Î¹ Î´á½³, ought to express something which tells against obedience (as the fear of a blind promise does); not something which tells in favour of it, as the fear of strife would do. The same objection applies to conjecturing á¼Ï€ÎµÎ»Î¸Îµá¿–Î½ (â€˜I am afraid of being drawn into such a strifeâ€™).

á½Î». á¼¦ Î¼á½´Î½ Ï„á½· Î´Ïá½±ÏƒÎµÎ¹Î½; ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„á½¹Î´â€™ á¼Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ïá½µÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹; ğŸ—©
Line 1186

á¼Î¾ÎµÎ¹Ïá½µÏƒÎµÏ„Î±Î¹; This is clearly the right punctuation; for Hyllus is most anxious to know what will be asked of him. Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸Î¿á¿¦, associate with thyself: cp. O. C.404 n.

Î´á½±Î¼Î±ÏÏ„Î±. This passage concerning IolÃ¨ and Hyllus (1216â€”1251) was rendered indispensable by the plot, if the poet was to avoid a contradiction which must otherwise have perplexed the spectators.

IolÃ¨ figured in legend as the wife of Hyllus. Their son, ÎšÎ»ÎµÎ¿Î´Î±á¿–Î¿Ï‚ (called ÎšÎ»ÎµÎ¿Î´á½±Ï„Î·Ï‚ by Theopompus, fr. 30), was mentioned by Hesiod (schol. Ap. Rh. 1. 824), and was recorded in the pedigree of the Spartan kings, being the grandfather of Aristodemus ( Her.6. 52Her., 8. 131). Hyllus and IolÃ¨ had also a daughter, Î•á½Î±á½·Ï‡Î¼Î·, known in Messenian story ( Paus.4. 2. 1).

But, in this play, IolÃ¨ is the paramour of Heracles, and indirectly the cause of his death. How, then, could Hyllus wed her? His own words (1233â€”1237) express what a Greek would feel. It was necessary, then, that the marriage should be imposed upon him by his dying father's inexorable command.

Cp. Apollodorus 2. 7. 7 Â§ 13 á¼Î½Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î»á½±Î¼ÎµÎ½Î¿Ï‚ á½Î»Î»á¿³...Ï„á½´Î½ á¼¸á½¹Î»Î·Î½ á¼€Î½Î´ÏÏ‰Î¸á½³Î½Ï„Î± Î³á¿†Î¼Î±Î¹: as if Hyllus were younger than Sophocles here imagines him. Ovid, Met.9. 278, of IolÃ¨: Herculis illam | Imperiis thalamoque animoque receperat Hyllus. Acc. to Pherecydes, it was for Hyllus, not for himself, that Heracles had first asked the hand of IolÃ¨ (schol. on v. 354).

In Latin, too, this natural laxity occurs: Offic. 1. 7 Â§ 22 ut placet Stoicis, quae in terris gignantur ad usum hominum omnia creari (instead of creantur).

Paley would get rid of the irregularity by making á½¡Ï‚ exclamatory (â€˜how!â€™): but this is impossible. The text is clearly sound, though it has been much suspected (cr. n.).

Î½ÎµÎ¼Îµá¿–Î½ â€¦ Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ±Î½: Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ± is the share of respect due to a person: cp. Plat. Crat. 398C Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î·Î½ Î¼Î¿á¿–ÏÎ±Î½ ÎºÎ±á½¶ Ï„Î¹Î¼á½´Î½ á¼”Ï‡ÎµÎ¹: and Soph. O. C.277Append. For Î½ÎµÎ¼Îµá¿–Î½, cp. 57 Î½á½³Î¼Î¿Î¹...á½¤ÏÎ±Î½.

Ï„á½¸ Ïƒá½¸Î½ Î¸ÎµÎ¿á¿–ÏƒÎ¹ Î´ÎµÎ¹ÎºÎ½á½ºÏ‚ á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½: the á¼”ÏÎ³Î¿Î½ is not, strictly, the marriage itself, but the act of Heracles in prescribing it. Line 12591259-1263

As Hyllus spoke the last two verses, he gave a sign to the bearers (964) to come forward and resume their places beside the litter. These five anapaestic lines are spoken by Heracles while that order is being obeyed. Then the words of Hyllus, Î±á¼´ÏÎµÏ„), á½€Ï€Î±Î´Î¿á½· (1264), mark that the procession is about to move.

á¼„Î³Îµ Î½Ï…Î½. Either Î½Ï…Î½ or Î½Ï…Î½ would be fitting here, but the former is better: it refers to the consent of Hyllus. The scholiast read Î½Ï…Î½ (á¼„Î³Îµ Î¿á½–Î½).

Line 1260

Ï€Ïá½¶Î½ á¼€Î½Î±ÎºÎ¹Î½á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ Ï„á½µÎ½Î´Îµ Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î½, â€˜before thou hast aroused this plague,â€™ i.e., â€˜allowed it to arise,â€™â€”by delay. The attacks recur at intervals; and he wishes to reach the pyre speedily (1253). The meaning is not that vehement laments might bring on the pain.

Other views are:â€”(1) á¼€Î½Î±ÎºÎ¹Î½á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ is intrans., â€˜be roused.â€™ But this use is unexampled, and cannot safely be inferred from the intrans. á½‘Ï€Î¿ÎºÎ¹Î½Îµá¿–Î½ ( Her.5. 106, etc.), or Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÎºÎ¹Î½Îµá¿–Î½ as=Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Îºá½¹Ï€Ï„ÎµÎ¹Î½, Ï€Î±ÏÎ±Ï€Î±á½·ÎµÎ¹Î½, delirare. (2) The subject to the inf. is Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î½, and the object is ÏƒÎµ understood. But á¼€Î½Î±ÎºÎ¹Î½á¿†ÏƒÎ±Î¹ clearly refers to rousing the pain, not to troubling the mind: cp. 974 Î¼á½´ ÎºÎ¹Î½á½µÏƒá¿ƒÏ‚...á½€Î´á½»Î½Î±Î½: 979 Îºá¼€ÎºÎºÎ¹Î½á½µÏƒÎµÎ¹Ï‚...Î½á½¹ÏƒÎ¿Î½.

á½¦ ÏˆÏ…Ï‡á½´ ÏƒÎºÎ»Î·Ïá½±: this phrase has a bad sense in Ai.1361; just as the epithet ÎºÏÎ±Ï„ÎµÏá½¹Ï†ÏÏ‰Î½, given to Heracles in Il.14. 324, is applied in Hes. Op.147 to the Ï‡á½±Î»ÎºÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½ Î³á½³Î½Î¿Ï‚.â€”Cp. Hom. Od.20. 18Ï„á½³Ï„Î»Î±Î¸Î¹ Î´á½´ ÎºÏÎ±Î´á½·Î·: Aristophanes parodies such passages, Ach.483 ff. Ï€Ïá½¹Î²Î±Î¹Î½Îµ Î½á¿¦Î½, á½¦ Î¸Ï…Î¼á½³...á¼„Î³Îµ Î½Ï…Î½, á½¦ Ï„á½±Î»Î±Î¹Î½Î± ÎºÎ±ÏÎ´á½·Î±: as Voltaire said of like apostrophes in Corneille, â€˜nous ne sommes plus dans un temps oÃ¹ l'on parle Ã  son bras et Ã  son Ã¢me.â€™

Ï‡á½±Î»Ï…Î²Î¿Ï‚ Î»Î¹Î¸Î¿Îºá½¹Î»Î»Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î¹Î¿Î½. This has been explained:â€”(1) â€˜A curb of steel, set with sharp stonesâ€™â€”to make it more severe. (2) â€˜A curb of steel, ornamented with costly stones.â€™ (3) â€˜A steel clamp for binding stones together.â€™ See Appendix.

I take the words in a way different from any of these. Ï‡á½±Î»Ï…Î²Î¿Ï‚ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î¹Î¿Î½, the â€˜curb of steel,â€™ is, as all agree, the strong selfrestraint which is to keep the lips closed. Then Î»Î¹Î¸Î¿Îºá½¹Î»Î»Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ introduces a new image. The lips, thus firmly closed, are set as stone to stone in masonry. Thus the whole phrase means â€˜A curb of steel, to keep the lips set as stone to stone.â€™ The use of Î»Î¹Î¸Î¿Îºá½¹Î»Î»Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ to describe the effect of the â€˜curbâ€™ has been assisted by the suggestion, in ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î¹Î¿Î½, of ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î±.

á¼€Î½á½±Ï€Î±Ï…Îµ Î²Î¿á½µÎ½. Pythagoras said that a dying man,â€”like one who is putting out to sea,â€”should avoid words of ill omen: â€”ÎºÎ±Ï„á½° Ï„á½¸Î½ á½•ÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¹Ïá½¸Î½ Ï€Î±Ïá½µÎ³Î³ÎµÎ»Î»Îµ Î¼á½´ Î²Î»Î±ÏƒÏ†Î·Î¼Îµá¿–Î½, á¼€Î»Î»â€™ á½¥ÏƒÏ€ÎµÏ á¼Î½ Ï„Î±á¿–Ï‚ á¼€Î½Î±Î³Ï‰Î³Î±á¿–ÏƒÎ¿á¼°Ï‰Î½á½·Î¶ÎµÏƒÎ¸Î±Î¹ Î¼ÎµÏ„â€™ Îµá½Ï†Î·Î¼á½·Î±Ï‚ (Iamblich. Pyth. Â§ 257).

á½¡Ï‚ with Ï„ÎµÎ»á½³Î¿Ï…Ï‚) (fut. part.), marking the intention (cp. 160): á¼Ï€á½·Ï‡Î±ÏÏ„Î¿Î½, predicative: (â€˜as being about to do a compulsory deed with a feeling of joy.â€™) The end has been imposed by fate; but it brings victory over pain.

Î»Î¹Î¸Î¿Îºá½¹Î»Î»Î·Ï„Î¿Î½ ÏƒÏ„á½¹Î¼Î¹Î¿Î½ Ï€Î±Ïá½³Ï‡Î¿Ï…Ïƒâ€™,

á½Î». Î±á¼´ÏÎµÏ„â€™, á½€Ï€Î±Î´Î¿á½·, Î¼ÎµÎ³á½±Î»Î·Î½ Î¼á½²Î½ á¼Î¼Î¿á½¶ ğŸ—©
Line 12641264-1278

The unanimous tradition assigned verses 1264â€”1274 to Hyllus. Verses 1275â€”1278 were given by some to the Chorus, and by others to Hyllus. From the indication in L at v. 1275 (Ï‡Î¿Ïá½¸Ï‚ Î³Ïá½±Ï†ÎµÏ„Î±Î¹ á½•Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚), and from the schol. there (Ï‡Î¿Ïá½¹Ï‚Â· Ï„Î¹Î½á½²Ï‚ á½•Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚), it may be conjectured that the attribution of 1275â€”1278 to the Chorus was the prevalent one. This was only natural, as the Chorus usually closes the play. A majority of modern editors, however, give vv. 1264â€”1278 wholly to Hyllus; and they seem right.â€”See Appendix.

á½€Ï€Î±Î´Î¿á½·, â€˜attendants,â€™ â€˜followers,â€™â€”the men who have come with him from Euboea (964). Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½–Î½ Î¼á½³Î»Î»Î¿Î½Ï„) Îº.Ï„.Î».: Hyllus means:â€”â€˜No one, indeed, commands a view (á¼Ï†Î¿Ïá¾·) of the future (and so it is possible that Zeus may yet make some amend); but, as to the present situation, it is miserable for us, shameful for Zeus (á¼ÎºÎµá½·Î½Î¿Î¹Ï‚), and supremely cruel for the victim.â€™

The words Ï„á½° Î¼á½²Î½ Î¿á½–Î½ Î¼á½³Î»Î»Î¿Î½Ï„â€™ Î¿á½Î´Îµá½¶Ï‚ á¼Ï†Î¿Ïá¾· unconsciously foreshadow the apotheosis of Heracles. This is the only hint of it in the play.

1275 Î»Îµá½·Ï€Î¿Ï… Î¼Î·Î´á½² Ïƒá½», Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½â€™, á¼€Ï€â€™ Î¿á¼´ÎºÏ‰Î½, ğŸ—©
Line 12751275-1278

These four verses are addressed by Hyllus to the leader of the Chorus, and give the signal for moving from the orchestra. With Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½), compare á½¦ Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½Î¿Î¹ in 211. The Chorus has been silent since 1113; and it seems dramatically right that its silence should be maintained in this last scene. The young maidens of Trachis may well leave the son of Heracles, at this solemn moment, to sum up the lesson of his father's fate.

If the verses are given to the leader of the Chorus, then Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½) will be taken in a collective sense, as referring to the other choreutae; cp. 821 á½¦ Ï€Î±á¿–Î´ÎµÏ‚. Prof. Campbell understands a reference to the maidens of the household (205); but this seems less natural. In either case, the singular number would be unusual.

Another view is that Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½) means IolÃ¨. But she is not present: and, even if she could be thus summoned forth, her presence would be unfitting.

á¼Ï€â€™ Î¿á¼´ÎºÏ‰Î½ (see cr. n.) is clearly right. á¼Ï€á½¶ is often thus used with the gen., of position: Plat. Charm. 163 B á¼Ï€â€™ Î¿á¼°Îºá½µÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î¸Î·Î¼á½³Î½á¿³: Thuc. 4. 118 Î¼á½³Î½ÎµÎ¹Î½ á¼Ï€á½¶ Ï„á¿†Ï‚ Î±á½‘Ï„á¿¶Î½.â€”The Vulg. á¼€Ï€) Î¿á¼´ÎºÏ‰Î½ has been explained in three ways, each of which appears untenable:â€”(1) â€˜Do not stay behind,â€”leaving the house,â€™ i.e., â€˜leave it.â€™ (2) â€˜Do not fail from the house,â€™â€”i.e., â€˜stay there.â€™ (3) With Ï€Î±ÏÎ¸á½³Î½): â€˜O maiden from the house, do not stay behind.â€™
